RATING: 6
Set collection/hand management with push your luck tension.

Yes it could basically be played with a regular deck of cards, and the theme is non-existent, and yes the card quality/choice is absolutely terrible (poor stock quality, black edges, and oversized preventing card sleeves- almost makes me think the design is intentional to make it like a disposable razor), BUT the gameplay is great.  It's definitely a wife-friendly game, it has some luck, but there's definitely tactics and strategy and it's overall addictive fun.  Simple, easy to play/learn, and worth the $18-20 you have to pay for the great idea contained in the "normal" deck of cards.

100603
Fun game, simple....you can pretty much approximate this with a deck of cards, but the art is pretty and it never hurts to support the designer.  
Update:  I like the game less and less every time I play it.  I guess its because I feel so constrained when I play the game.  You make decisions at the beginning at the game and at some point it just feels like you're just playing it out.  Its now a 4 and may well go lower soon.
Update2: Talked about it with my girlfriend, she pointed out mistakes I made during the play tried it again tonight, its back to a 6.  You do have a bit more control than I realized.  I thought it was missing a tactical element, but it was just that i wasn't paying attention.  Also would have been better if we were playing 3 rounds with the winner at the end - that would create a story arc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Big fan of Lost Cities.  Very simple game to understand, but there's a lot of strategy.  I also love that you can basically chose how long you want the game to be.  You can play one round if you wanted a quick game or you could play nine rounds if you wanted an epic game.  My S.O. and I normally play medium-length at 3-5 rounds. 

Scoring system is very well designed and forces players to evaluate risk / reward of every expedition and card play.  The game can frustrate a lot of people since you are frequently forced to make undesirable decisions, but it's really a matter of minimizing the harm, and maximizing potential reward. 

Only downside to the game is that there is a significant luck element in which cards you draw.  However, I find that this normally evens out when playing a 5+ round game. 

I'm giving it a "8" for strategy, fun, and short / flexible length of the game.  It's not the perfect strategy game, but it's one that I'm almost always in the mood for, and I have not grown tired of at all after a dozen plus plays. 


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Simple to learn, harder to master.  You can learn to play this in minutes but it will take a few plays to figure out the nuances.  Fast and fun so you can play many times in a session.  No direct interaction with your opponent - you play your cards on your cards and discard to common discard piles and draw from a single draw pile until it is exhausted.  Game ends when draw pile is depleted and with both players holding a full hand of cards.  The interaction with your opponent is more about misdirection of your intentions and what cards to show him or continue to hold in your hand.

RATING: 9
Uber easy, yet deep.  You take some risks and sometimes it pays off big time, otherwise it doesn't.  After I read all the indepth reviews I was beginning to wonder why I ordered it.  Normally I don't want a card game involving numbers.  I tend to think of it as just more darned Rummy or Rook.  Well, I was wrong.  This is a great game and another reason I'm learning to love Knizia.  This game is just such a great pick-up game for 2 people, beautifully done.  The board and cards just add to the flavor of the game.  I originally expected something a lot different based on the description so I was disappointed... until I actually played it!  Awesome game for 2 players.  Highest marks for sure!

RATING: 8
I really enjoy this one... it's light, it has a fun theme, yet there is a suprising amount of depth to it. I hope to have more plays of this one... it's giving Battle Line some good competition. I love how you can take the top cards on the discard piles... it opens up some really interesting opportunities.After playing this quite a bit more, I have to rate it above Battle Line. The replayability and universal appeal of this game make it win for me. I'll still keep Battle Line but it probably won't see as much play... at least not until I wear this one out.

RATING: 9
Our favourite quick filler. Hundreds of games, and the cards are holding up well. Easy to get some games in before dinner. Terrific.

We are now on our 4th copy of this game, having given away our playing copies to friends. The cards are now sleeved and it is even lovelier to play, in a tactile sense, and this copy should last forever.

One copy we gave away to friends living on their yacht in Bundaberg, truly became Lost Cities when their yacht with all their posessions was totally lost in the flood in January 2013. At least they had some fun with it before the game went on its own acquatic expedition.

RATING: 7
6+ plays / 2 players

LIKE: Getting a new card every round to see what you get. The ascending order restriction is fun. Fun to push-your-luck to try to get just the right cards.
DISLIKE: Lots of math to score the game end.

OVERALL: Brilliant game. My wife enjoys this as it's simple to understand and plays quickly, but deep. Strategy wasn't apparent until after a couple of plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2016-02-11
7->6
It is hard to say whether Lost Cities is a masterpiece or just an average game. If you are the owner, you love it because it is easy to teach and to carry with you. If you are just a player, you love it because it is easy to learn, plays quick and offers meaningful decisions to make. There are few other games that are so simple but still offer a healthy amount of things to ponder.

To answer my initial question, I have to say that I am inclined to put Lost Cities into the category of good averages. This is because in the long run the game becomes a bit repetitive. By this I am referring to the fact that most of the time you are just making wild guesses when starting an expedition. Of course, you can try to read your opponent's hand and thus make good or better guesses, but still most of the excitement in drawing the cards.

Nevertheless, Lost Cities is a good 2-player game for occasional playing.

2008-07-10
Easy to learn but because of the luck factor can never be truly mastered. Good planning is still needed though. A light game to play even with my parents.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably the best two player German-style game I've played.  It has the stamp of genius...simple but clever and deep.  The hardest decisions sometimes have to be made and it can be painful to discard a card that you know your opponent may want or that you are likely to want later.  It's amazing how often you play a card and then find that the one you pick up could ideally have been played before it.  Lots of thought goes into each game and yet you are never left with a headache.  How can such a simple concept be this good?  In addition, my wife adores it, and so I can almost gaurantee a game of it anytime I like.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Has the feel of [thing=760][/thing], but much more simple.  It lacks direct conflict, but is not a boring multi-player solitaire game, as many Euros are.  It has a passive-aggressive component to it, where you can do things like draw from the draw deck to speed the game up and keep the other guy from meeting his goals, or holding on to cards that he desperately needs.  Best part it plays quickly -- VERY quickly, and is a lot of fun in a small, quick package.  Also, a big plus with small children (about 3rd grade): it teaches math without being boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

I think I could actually use this as a gateway game for several friends.

RATING: 7
Game of strategy.  Pts are earned by taking journeys.  To start a journey costs you to begin at negative twenty, y ou may begin playing multipliers, your goal to get rid of the negatives and into positive.  A game consists of three rounds.  Good mathematics here and practice with integer operations.  A round ends when the deck of cards runs out.  Cards in your hands do not hurt you, only the cards played.  Be careful you must balance playing cards and  yes if you are not wise you may be feeding  your opponent pts.

RATING: 7
It is mystifying to us how this is such a standard recommendation for 2-player games.  It is no worse than many conventional card games, but if you have a deck of cards and a copy of Hoyle's you can play better games than this -- and not pay $20, or wonder "what's the hype about?"  The claims of very deep strategy (don't discard things your opponent needs -- really?) don't convince me.

Compare with Battle Line:  even the standard rules (with tactics + 10s, no play on taken stones) are a vastly superior game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lost Cities consists consists of 1 simple boardgame and 60 cards.  There are just 5 spaces on the board with different colours.  Cards were also separated into these respective colours with ascending numbers and multiplier effect cards.

At the start of the game, players starts with 8 cards.  They can choose to discard their cards or place cards for play by placing coloured cards onto the board of the same colour.  By placing a number cards on the board, the column that the player played starts with -20 points.  Before number cards were played, multiplier cards can be played.  Multiplier cards can double/ triple or quadruple your score (depending on the number of multiplier cards are played), but it will also cause you to start with a more negative points (also dependent on the number of multiplier cards played).  

Whenever a card is played or discard, player can draw a new card, either from the discard pile or from the new deck of cards.  The game ends when the new deck of cards are all drawn by players.  As the result, players can prolong or shorten the game by taking cards from the discard pile or from the new deck respectively.

Good points: The game has simple rules and involves some strategies during play.  The game is good for people who like short games.

Bad points: The game invloves in some luck when drawing of the cards.  However I think it could be offset by placing cards wisely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Read my review here: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1678729/settlers-stavanger-reviews-lost-cities

This is a great little 2-player card game with a surprising amount of strategy given how quick it is to play and how easy it is to explain to new players. 

This is a favourite of my wife and I and due to it's small size it's ideal for taking on holiday with us. The fact that you play "best of 3" as recommended by the rules means that the winner isn't necessarily so clear after the first game as it can change drastically between games.

RATING: 7
A press-your-luck exercise from Herr Knizia. It's beautifully implemented, and surprisingly thematic for a Knizia title: if you don't invest enough, the expedition will fail, but if you overinvest, your opponents will overtake you. This is what Victorian treasure-hunting should feel like, I think.

2

The theme, as all Kinizia games tend to be, is a bit thin, but it might be the most elegant game in my collection, where elegance is defined as simplicity in design/mechanic and depth in both tactical and strategic decision making.

RATING: 9
Good two player game with some fun, fast decisions.  

An ideal filler for two to play while waiting for another game with gamer friends to finish:  you can play 1 round in five minutes, 2 rounds in ten minutes, and so on.  Giving it a 7.  May 2012.

Okay, although this is quite simple, and can feel a bit auto-pilot mindless at times, the design and experience are quite good.  Raising it to an 8.  October 2014.  

This game manages to please and intrigue just about everyone who plays it for the first time, particularly non-gamers, and its design manages to pack many "good game" design principles into a very small package.  Simply put, the game decisions are interesting and pleasing on many different levels.  With some hesitation, but respect necessitated by several key factors, going to raise this to a 9.  August 2015.

RATING: 8
it took us a long time to give this game a try mainly because it has Knizia's name on it and we not liked any of his games so far. But when you hear Tom Vasel talk about a game enough you just have to break down and give it a try. And you know what? It is a very good hand management, set collection game with some really tight strategy. The only thing we don't like about it is that wonky scoring. Add up the numbers on the cards, multiply it by the number of this type of card  then subtract 20? It doesn't seem to complicated but we are always having to refer back to the rules and a calculator to see who won. Why does he always have to make scoring in his games so complicated?

RATING: 8
RK knows the gamers thrills, and he hits the sweet spot once again for me on this 2-player card game.  While the game isn't much to behold on paper, it becomes much more addicting in real life.  The games go by so quick, and that irrefutable human itch to balance and weigh points and risk, is scratched well, thank you.  However once worn, I am not sure I feel as if it was life-changingly innovative.  It seems to follow the rules all too well, I need this game to be more wild and funky, with some character to impress me up to a 10.

___________________
\_______GER_______/
Der geistige Urvater von [thing=34585]Keltis[/thing] (na ja wenn man bedankt, daß das Spiel schon 20 Jahre auf dem Buckel hat, auch kein Wunder).
Die Aufmachung der Karten gefällt mir ziemlich gut. Das Thema einer Expedition bleibt zwar trotz der stimmungsvollen Spielkarten und dem Spielbrett mit den Schatzkartenmotiven recht abstrakt. Aber mit etwas gutem Willen und Fantasy kann man sich so die -20 Startpunkte pro Expedition doch erklären. 
Ich hatte mich von den sehr einfachen Regeln täuschen lassen aber im Laufe des ersten Spiels dann auch schnell verstanden, daß dieses Spiel nicht einfach eine weitere Multiplayer-Solitair Version ist. Man kann schon auf die Züge des Mitspielers agieren und reagieren. Wenn man gegen Ende des Spiels merkt, daß es ein Zeitproblem gibt um seine tolle Expedition von der Hand bis zum Spielende ausgelegt zu bekommen, dann kann schon Spannung aufkommen. Es kann taktisch klug sein das Spiel zu Verlängern in dem man keine neuen Karten vom Hauptkartensstapel sondern alte evt. unbrauchbare Karten von den 5 Ablagestapeln zu nehmen. Aber evt. wäre es doch besser so schnell wie möglich das Spiel vor seinem Gegenspieler zu beenden bevor der seine Expeditionen mehr als ab bezahlt hat. 
Gutes und schnelles 2 Personenspiel zum Entspannen.
Die Abrechnerei am Ende kann evt. etwas abschreckend wirken (vor allem beim ersten Erklären der Regeln ...) 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The girlfriend LOVES this game, which is a big plus for me (as she rarely likes or will play anything).  She'll even bring it up to me just randomly to play.  

Outside of her, I would think this game is still pretty good, but probably not AS good.  A lot of it seems to be timing, as well as some risk vs. reward management.  You could hold cards in your hand until you're 100% sure you'll make a profit.  Or you could risk it, put down some investments, and hope for a good payout.  

And of course, the theme is wholly pasted on, but I guess that's pretty expected.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite two player only games.  There are five different colors and each color has cards labeled 1-9 with three multiplier cards for each color as well.  Object is to stack the cards sequentially (starting with a multipliers if you want to risk it) and at the end of the draw stack you tally your scores.  Here is the kicker though.  You score negative points if you have a stack that has less than 20 points in it.  Each stack you subtract 20 from to get the final score.  That's to keep you from just placing in each color and to make it more complex.  It's mathy but fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

RATING: 6

In the first 16 games, I have won 2 against her. I've grown to admire and enjoy this game. It has what I'd call indirect interaction and it's cleverly integrated in this surprisingly good game.

RATING: 10
Part of my rating may be nostalgia since I was playing this regularly before I even discovered BGG. However, there is so much more to take into account such as its simplicity, its depth, its conceit, the blend of strategy and tactics, the art, the over-sized cards, the tiny box, how unique it was at the time (and maybe how unique it is now), how the tension builds throughout the game, how the choices become immediately difficult, how players have a little control over when the game will end, et cetera. I will never turn down a game of Lost Cities. I am not afraid to give it a 10.

RATING: 6
1/31/07
This is a nice card game.  I wasn't expecting much from this game but it is pretty good and I enjoy it.  It is a much more toned down of Battle Line.  I actually have a strong urge to play this game again and would suggest to play the game.  However, I don't think the feelings will stay because of it's shallow depth.  I think I would still play this even if I have Battle Line.  I am now deciding if I should get it or not, since I already have Battle Line.  
Initial Rating: 7

Update: 2/16/07
After playing it 55 times in BSW.  I think I like this only on BSW because it is very fast and all the accounting is taken care for me.  I don't have to count the cards afterwards and I don't have to shuffle the cards either.  Each game round only lasts an average of two minutes and off we go to start another round.  I think if I played this face to face, a lot of the charm of a QUICK simple game is lost and I would be bored to tears playing this game.  Having Battle Line IS sufficient and I'll only play this game on BSW.  Since all my ratings are based on face-to-face games, this is a 6.
Update: 7 -> 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial Impression: A very simple game with some surprisingly tough decisions. Play a card, pick a card. However, do you discard a card and hope that your opponent can't use it, or do you begin an expedition even though that might not net you the most points. This makes a good gateway game and can be played very quickly. My only beef is the endgame scoring can be fiddly.

10 Plays: I'm still enjoying this game. Once you've played regularly with an opponent, the game quickly evolves into a mindgame where you need to bluff your opponent into discarding the wrong cards. Setting the pace for the endgame is a very powerful tool in that regard. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There's a lot to enjoy with Lost Cities. I like that the simple rules lead to difficult choices, and often, any card you play could help your opponent more than it does you. If not for this factor, it would rate a point lower, since endgames can become a card churning exercise once you have completed all your expeditions and are striving to exhaust the draw pile.

This is a game that frequently hits the table. My wife likes it and plays it well. Lost Cities is one of the best games to teach non gamers what great games are available today.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Based on the description, I was expecting more than the box provided.  This game is basically a deck of cards, made up of 5 different colors.  Players start "expeditions" by playing cards of the same color in numerical order.  Doesn't really have the feel of an expedition, but it's about as fun as a traditional card game.  However, why should people buy a $20 card game when they have the option of playing over 500 games with a standard deck of cards?  Lost Cities can be addicting for some people, but the same can be said for traditional card games, such as Spades, Hearts, Canasta, etc.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I just can't see what there is about Lost Cities that makes people choose such a mediocre game as a favourite. I mean surely there have to be a bunch of better games than this.  Lost Cities lacks any sense that the theme is meaningful - this could just as easily be a game about cooking pizza, washing dishes or cycle touring.  It lacks depth, and I don't feel it does much more than what a traditional card game like Patience does - all it does is present what amounts to a traditional card game in a nice flashy graphics package - but underneath the make-up it's still basically a variant of Patience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[i]Posted: 10/3/05, Rated: 8[/i]

A solid two-player game.  It has been compared to [i][thing=15878]Rummy[/thing][/i], but I find that analogy to be misleading.  [i]Lost Cities[/i] is its own beast.

The "theme" such as it is fits well enough: you are potentially embarking on up to five expeditions that are represented by card colors (or suits).  The art on the cards is very appropriate, but the cards themselves are too big.  They feel "floppy" when shuffling.  The game wouldn't have suffered any had they been standard bridge-deck size.

The scoring calculations are slightly convoluted: starting an expedition automatically incurs a -20 point penalty.  This value represents the initial cost to embark upon the adventure.  The cards that you play afterwards defray that cost, and hopefully result in a net profit.  There are "handshakes" (investor cards) that act as score multipliers, but they must be played first.  They increase the risk and also the possible reward.  All cards are played or discarded face-up, which is important since you and your opponent will probably be vying for the same cards in at least one suit.

The heart of the game is found in trying to maximize the returns from your own expeditions while inhibiting your opponent's efforts.  You can only hold eight cards in your hand, and it is never enough.  You will have to take risks by beginning an expedition before you have enough support for it, or by discarding something your opponent may be able to use.  A particularly frustrating development occurs when you start an expedition for which you have several cards, none of which are handshakes.  Sure enough, as soon as you play the first numeric card, your opponent will start to discard those handshakes.

My wife enjoys this game, and is rapidly becoming a shark at it.  After ten plays or so, I'd be more likely to rate [i]Lost Cities[/i] a "7," but it does get a bonus point for sparking her interest in games.

[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=14]BGWS Review[/url]

All around a good game.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is our (travel) game of choice. neither one of us has EVER turned down a game, not even during our 2 month cycling trip when we played hundreds of games and you would expect us, towards the end, to be so sick of it, that we would try out its absorption capacity when we realised we overlooked packing some other essentials.

I suspect that if we had to get rid of our entire game collection, these 60 cards would still be the last ones to go. Pathetically simple rules, with dilemmas in each and every turn of a fast and involving game. Apart from a lifelong replacement service for worn cards, there is not much to improve on this classic 2 player game. You can take it anywhere (we have tried), play it on just about any surface (ditto, often intriguing the hell out of onlookers), it is so quick that it  invites many instant replays, and it appeals to gamers from all ages and levels of experience. No wonder, since it is challenging from the opening hand, to timing the play of those last high value cards. Brilliance in a nutshell. Luck, skill, gambling and (blocked) hand management balanced to perfection. The 20 point "hurdle", the frequency of doublers and the temptation to hang on to obtain more vs the need to play cards to keep the hand flowing, the capacity to slow the game down by picking up discards, or NOT, psyching out the hand of your opponent, and trying to survive my favourite gamble: 3 jokers with nothing to back it up. Love it, love it, love it.

4 PLAYER VARIANT:
We have recently started to play the 4 player version again, and I forgot how much I enjoyed that (too). A completely different game evolves, where the end always comes quicker than expected. Making the most of a poor or excellent hand is the loveliest dance each team can be put through. Figuring out what your partner is flagging with the cards they pass on is a nice addition, but deciding when to play and when to leave that to your partner is especially engrossing, even more so since turns are so precious. It seems to be more important than in the 2 player game to make sure that the chances you do get to score high are executed to perfection. If you have a chance to explore the less trodden 4 player path, grab it!

RATING: 5
[url=http://ballearicus.blogspot.com/2007/06/exploradores-lost-cities-1999.html]Exploradores[/url] es un juego sencillo, a veces tengo la sensación de jugar al cinquillo. Asimilar los conceptos básicos del juego, sus posibilidades y las diferentes tácticas se desvelan por si solas a las pocas partidas. Decir el juego que está bastante equilibrado y que su alto factor azaroso compensa el desequilibrio de nivel que pueda haber entre jugadores, lo que lo hace idóneo para pasar el rato con neófitos.

Exploradores es un juego de relleno, portable, para jugadores ocasionales, neófitos o simplemente matar un rato.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Often times in lost cities, you're holding cards that the other player wants and that you want to hold onto but you have to get rid of one. Do you give the other player what they want or discard something you want? 

Add this to cards where you bet on your own success in a  pretty lucky game and that's where all the fun is. Things may just work out based on your educated guess or maybe not. You take the risk anyway because you need to make up points for the last round you did so poorly in. 

All around a satisfying two player card game where all you do is take a card and play a card. A game I like because I can just shuffle, deal, and play.

Sleeved

// We've played this game quite a bit. It may as well be
themeless, but the mechanics of the game are reasonably 
fun. The tough choices involve when to start a new set of
cards - and whether to place a bet on actually getting 
very far with that set. Meanwhile, your opponent is 
weighing the same decisions and may be interfering with
your plans. I wasn't a huge fan of the scoring in this game
at first, but after playing it more, it works well enough.

RATING: 9
About as most perfect a two-player card game as you can hope to find. It seems so simple that you're always amazed it ends up so agonizing and cutthroat at the end (but this never generates any hard or hurt feelings between the two players, as it is completely obvious the other player is trying to do the same thing to you!). And then it's over before it has a chance to get boring. WONDERFULLY balanced. Love it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
20 plays: 

A perfect balance. Nice, light feeling but quite deep variation on the Fantan type of paying cards game. Simple and well made components. 

The theme and art are well done.

I like the amount of strategy and information-tracking: enough to make a difference, but not so much that players get paralyzed. The game flows well, and you finish wanting to play again.

It shines not so much in the depth of any one decision point, but in the enjoyable exploration of slightly different strategies as you play the game more times. In that sense, it's very similar to Jaipur.

The points based system makes it feel anticlimactic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
I played this once, didn't like it, won, played it again, didn't like it and lost ;-). It moves fast, real fast, mainly because I found almost zip to think about, draw, play, draw, play, draw, play one card after the other, th outcome decided by two factors - risk taken and sheer luck. The more risk you take up front, the greater the sink or swim pressure, but ultimately to make the 20 points onece starting ane expedition you must eithe rbe delath the cards up front, draw them form the deck or have an opponent forced to discard one you fortuitously need. To cap it off, there's a mad rush at the end to try and play all the cards you still have in hand and had been sitting on in the hope of bridging the huge gaps under them (which are sealed and point-less once you play them).

In short, didn't do it for me. EIther I haven't worked out the joy or subtley in this or others juts enjoy basic luck games without either a strong social or thematic angle to them.

RATING: 6
I may be picky, but I have a REAL problem with scoring that is this byzantine. Game is fine, cool even, but then the arrhythmic... I mean, there are probably apps to smooth that out, and sure, it's not like I hate every game where the scoring is a bit brutal (Yes... precious... Arboretum...) but this one just seems to pale when compared to modern 2 player fare. Modern two player games that, incidentally, tend to have theme. 

Now I will confess it also could just be that this is a Knizia, who I have just recently purged from my collection, as... well, I've decided that his games just aren't my bag. It could also be that I'm a bit cult of the new, but I think lack of theme and scoring really sums it up for me on this one. Now, lets go play Arboretum... confused yet? So am I.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In [b]Lost Cities[/b], you collect numbered cards in colour sets to score expeditions.  Actually, LC is an abstract card game with an archaeological theme pasted on.  The rules are very simple, but the games become surprisingly strategic.

Great boyfriend-girlfriend game.

RATING: 10
When this game came out, I didn't appreciate it that much; I liked the agonizing decisions, but I don't think I really understood *why* they were agonizing, and as such, that limited my appreciation for the game. Now that I understand Lost Cities as fundamentally a game of risk management, rather than a game of tactics, I like it much better. That tricky Reiner, always packing so much more into games than it seems on first inspection; such elegance and subtlety. There's a reason that he's the best there is.

RATING: 6
It's Rack-o! OK, OK, it's an improvement on Rack-o. Actually, probably an idealized version of Rack-o. 

All right, all right, I just like saying Rack-o.

Anyway, good press-your-luck flavored rummyish game that (surprise surprise) is my wife's favorite game. What is it about non-gamers that makes this their favorite game?

Update (after 22 plays): A simple, elegant, and enduring 2-player card game with elements of set collection and press-your-luck. The connection to the theme of exploring ancient ruins is pretty tenuous, but it isn't really necessary anyway - Cribbage, Hearts, Bridge, and Rummy do just fine without any themes at all.

RATING: 8
Pros:
Excellent scoring mechanism.
Many opportunities for decisions.
A unique press-your-luck style of strategy.

Cons:
The board and tarot-sized cards are utterly superfluous, serving only to make the game twice as expensive as a pure card game would be.
The luck of the draw aspect of this game frustrates me every single time I play, to the point that I don't have fun anymore.
Too many games end by one player having a slightly lower NEGATIVE score than the opponent.

Overall, I'm always intrigued by the game and willing to play, but I just can't catch the fire of this one like I can other Knizia classics.

[b]Edit[/b] I've raised my rating from a 6 to an 8. I've been enjoying this much more recently. There are still things that irritate me a little about it but overall this is fun game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After more plays i realize that Lost Cities is a deep game.  Initially I thought Lost Cities was a  childishly simple,  but after repeated play it is a game of serious risk management.  

The game became a 10 when I learned some new strategies.  I hold off playing cards to find the investment (multipliers) cards, stall by playing cards to break even one color to buy time to score some big points for another and other techniques.

I look forward discovering new strategies.  

Scoring is too complicated.  Should be an easier way like in Lost Cities the board game.

RATING: 6
Based on game play alone I'd only give this a 6 but, like Battle Line and Blue Moon City, Lost Cities offers a great "value" in terms of the game play given for the modest effort and time required and for that it gets an 8. RATING: 9
For replayability alone, I'd have rated this a 9. However, there's more: Knizia has created a deceptively simple game that requires players to learn distinctively different mechanism for the beginning-game, mid-game, and end-game phases. And there's a tempting "push-your-luck" element: you must be a wise investor and sometimes curb (and sometimes indulge!) the impulse to "go big" with the colors you decide to start "adventures" in. Highly recommended. Packs a lot of fun into a short time.

RATING: 8
This is definitely a great tense game where you have to play or discard, and playing often means giving up potential points, and discarding means helping your opponent.

The flaw in the game, for me, is that while low cards are important for the bonus points, a player who sees more high point cards than the other has a huge advantage.

However, for me, Schotten Totten does everything this game does, but better, tighter, more elegant.

Bonus points for being easy-to-explain, portable, approachable, and newbie-friendly.

RATING: 8
[u]January 10:[/u] A very fast-paced 2 player game. Theme is irrelevant but that doesn't bother me much. I prefer Lost Cities to BattleLine. This is a game you want to play over and over again.

[u]March 2010:[/u] Was writing [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/505083/multiple-player-review-lost-cities]a review[/url] and realized I had to bump the rating one notch. Went from 7.5 to 8.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost Cities is nothing like Battle Line in my opinion! Well, “nothing like” is probably too strongly worded, but I had always been under the impression that those two games are very similar. The way you need to play cards in order to get points are very different I think. In BL there is much more interaction as you compete directly against each other in order to win flag. There are also the tactic cards which have a big impact on the gameplay. Finally, you build pokerhands in BL, whereas you simply play cards from 1 to 10 in LC… In LC the interaction is very limited (except when you’re discarding cards face-up in the middle, as you need to keep a close eye on which cards the other player can use – this is a great feature). LC is a much more casual and easy-going game, so I honestly don’t think the games have too much in common, and I don’t think you’ll necessarily like one if you like the other. 

To me, LC is the better game as I feel it’s a little more relaxing and without too many hard decisions. It’s better suited for non-gamers or casual play. The time to play feels just about right. Sure, there is the luck of the draw; if you get a couple of the hand multipliers and some high cards in the same suit, you’ll have a big advantage, but that’s why you play three games and compare scores. And despite the luck of the draw there is still room for clever play: when to discard which cards, how many expeditions to start (as you lose points if you start a mission that fails to reach 20+ points, which is probably the best thing about the game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Clever game with tough choices. I am awful at this game. I always seem to start too many expeditions. I like how the card art matches up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fantastic little card game.  It's one game my partner loves to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I expected more of this one. Known as excellent 2 player tactical/strategical game, I found this one to be to luck dependant. Prefer Keltis.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This one appeals to me in the same regard that Carcassonne does. Even though the games are very different, they are both very attractive and enjoyable as an activity. I can play the game, think a little bit, and still have a good conversation with a friend. Enjoyable.

Scoring is clever, even if a bit mathy. 

I know people on the geek say it is over-rated, but I think they are forgetting that the rating is for how frequently you would play it. This game is accessible and appeals to a wide audience. The rating is not for "How much it makes me feel like a true and noble gamer." 

I like the board even though it is unnecessary. 

I love the theme connected with the game. Pasted on? I daringly say,"NO!" The excellent execution of the progressive art and design capture my imagination fully. The game is beautiful, the design is tight. Here is my test for theme: while playing, can I make a bold or colorful move and then joke about what must have happened to reflect that move in terms of the theme.

Theme = does it capture my imagination enough that I can explain my moves in terms of the theme. Think about it: can anybody explain to me why the harvests speed up in Agricola and why my young child is able to work in the fields in strict theme terms? No. It makes sense because it is a Euro-game. I don't see anybody talking about how pasted on the theme in Agricola is. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I think Schotten-Totten and Balloon Cup are far superior.  The early-game guesswork about where to open expeditions feels too random to me, and the dilemmas in this game just aren't much fun to me.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good filler game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Read the rules and thought, "Eh. Not bad." Then ran through a solo dummy game and thought "pretty good I suppose." Then played the first game with my wife, and all the agonizing choices came to the forefront. Played a 2nd game immediately after the first. 

This game is a great introduction to two-player-only gaming, or "spouse gaming." In fact, this game might be the game that kicked off weeknight gaming as a mutual hobby with my wife and a way to wind down after a work day. It's also the game in my collection that shows the most wear and abuse, with 70+ plays taking a toll on the cards. Not a bad purchase, eh?

We've since moved on to other and slightly more heavy games, graduating to Jaipur, Roma, Dominion, two-player Puerto Rico, and so on and so on. But this is the game that really started it, and it's deceptive combination of simple rules and tough choices stood up for quite some time.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great 2 player card game that we finally got to the table. It plays super quick and the artwork is awesome. In  our first few games it was apparent that you can play to any number of columns and have a chance to win, which is great as you can play different strategies each game based on your starting hand. Also, by being forced to play the investments first it is a bit of press your luck as you will need to hope to get some high number cards in that color later on to ensure you get a positive score for that color. My only complaint is the scoring is a little hard to wrap your head around (it was late and we have 2 kids, what can I say), but I imagine it goes quicker with more plays. I can easily see this one coming out frequently.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So, the *same* day I make a comment in a Geeklist that I haven't played Lost Cities ("I feel like less of a woman"), I end up...playing Lost Cities for the first time.  The irony was too much to pass up when it was suggested as a game.

WHY is this game suggested so often as a "game for non-gamers to try"?  It's all right as a 2-player game, pretty dependent on card-drawing luck and a little on bluffing and timing, and easy to explain.  It's not unusual or stellar though--but maybe that's why it's used as an intro game?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lost Cities is the definitive champion of the "least bad decision" genre.  Your first few plays may be straightforward, but from then on every draw leads to a delightfully nightmarish choice.

RATING: 7.5
Players: 2

Really great card game for 2 players. Your strategy builds as more cards are laid on the table, be it in your own piles or your opponents. A lot of "press your luck" in that if you wait too long for your ideal card, you'll end up with nothing (or less than nothing!). The theme is icing on the cake.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great game when you only have a few minutes or are stuck at the airport during the annual air traffic control strike.

NB
I'm becomming aware that abstract games are not my taste and this refects in my opinion of many games).  The theme on many simple games are painted on to level I find difficult.

Games in this grouping:
Taluva
Lost Cities
Bohanza
Jet Set
Junta
Enemy in Sight
Naval War

Some more complex game have a level of abstration that does not meet my expectation for the theme/subject etc.  This makes the game a less compelling experience.

Games in this grouping:
Elder Signs
Reef Encounter
Modern Naval Battles
The Fury of Dracula

My enthusiasm for these games is limited by a level of abstraction that challenges my taste and my rating reflects this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Anyone reading this, please recommend more quick, 2 player games like this.  My library is getting too many large games that I just don't have time to play enough in order to get my fix.

RATING: 9
Very simple game, but the great thing about it is the tension it generates.  You don't want to help your opponents, but there's times you might have to discard a card you think they'll use. You don't always want to start or continue a play (expedition) right away, but you may be running out of turns or your hand is too full and you have to do something.  You have to balance taking too many expeditions with taking too few and you're also trying to figure out what your opponent is doing.  Then there's always doubling or tripling or quadrupling down on your expeditions making them even more important to at least break even.  Again it's a simple game, but the quick play and tension makes it addicting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think I like this game more than Keltis/Lost Cities. The lack of duplicate cards as well as as the fact that it's two-player make this far more cut-throat than its cousins. Handshakes can be a bit tricky to pull off, but determinijng the perfect moment to start an expedition (ideally your second or third) along with some extra investment is a game in itself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of our favorite two player games at the moment. Definitely a lot of luck influence which can lead to frustration. It's amazing how much the point totals swing (all the way from negative points to near-triple digits). So you can play two really bad rounds and still come back to win it. That makes it fun but also pretty annoying. 

I play roughly the same each round, but there's room for some modification based on 1) what cards emerge, and 2) the opponent's choices. If my opponent is going high-risk, piling up wager cards, I tend to respond with defense and conservative play, drawing out the deck quickly. Sometimes the key to winning is to not play every awesome card you hold or even to give up big points in order to accomplish your plans. I like these choices and the inevitable times that my best hopes and plans are thwarted by unlucky draws end up being less devastating because the game is short. If the game was even a little longer or more invested, those kinds of things would drive me crazy!  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Egyszerű játék. Reiner Knizia készítette ami magában hordozza a matek jellegét a játéknak.
"Igazából a játékrendszer nem követelte volna meg ezt a témát, de gondolom, így jobban el tudják adni, mint ha csak egy száraz, matematikai alapokon nyugvó számolásos kártyajáték volna." /Hosaka/
Számomra ez az egyetlen negatívuma, túlságosan látszik a matematikai kötődés és ez mindig zavar - amikor éppen nem játszom vele. Ha épp kalandozunk az 5 világban, akkor rá se hederítek. :)
Felvezető-bevezető játéknak kiváló.

Kedveljük ezt az egyszerű, szép és gyors játékot. Szerintem 60 kártyáért és 1 játéktáblárt szörnyű 4000 forintot elkérni (van ahol jóval többe kerül). Hosaka 2004-ben elkészített egy házi változatot (aminek a design-ja nekem jobban is tetszik mint az eredetié), érdemes rákeresni neten és otthon legyártani a táblát meg a 60 kártyát! :)

Játszási szám: több, mint 10
Amióta megvan: 2009.tavasz

RATING: 9
Great game with beautiful artwork - I enjoy both LC and LCtBG.  I like the card game because of the quick set up vs. the more fiddly set up of the board game.  The card game feels much more frenetic and tense to me because of the faster pace and this is something my husband enjoys.  It seems like just as you've gotten your expeditions on track, the draw pile is already 2/3 gone and you'd better get those high cards out or you'll be stuck with them in your hand!  Also much more difficult to discard because most of the time it seems your opponent will need the cards you want to toss.  I really enjoy the slower pace of LCtBG as a family game -- LC the card game is great to play with my husband.

RATING: 2.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Lost Cities has a subject so thin you coud shave with it. The cards, while beautifully illustrated, are not pleasant to shuffle and handle due to their size. The board is not needed for play. The scoring system is artificial. Okay, that sums up a lot of modern-style boardgames, so I can't really hold it against the game. What I [i]do[/i] hold against this title is the absence of interesting strategies: luck and a bit of elemental tactics are all you need. And that's precisely the rub. If both players use the best available tactics, it becomes the luck of the draw. If one of them doesn't, the other is bored stiff from lack of interesting play. I had a nice time figuring out the game, but after a while it grew repetitive because the decisions all amounted to the same thing. I tried playing it online, and turned away in disgust after seeing how bad people were. I haven't played it since, and prefer games with a bit more meat on their bones.

[b]Update[/b] Replayed after what seems an eternity. Yep, still boring luck of the draw and fixed strategies and tactics. Glad to be done with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Such a fun, light game and yet so addicting.  I play online all the time.  Can't stop! :)

RATING: 10

The rules are relatively easy to learn and the scoring is straightforward.  There is more strategy than one might initially expect.  I think it's disgusting that so many people have relegated this game to "spouse-only" status when it's worthy of so much higher regard.

RATING: 6
PLayed this once awhile back.  Not bad...it's a good, quick, scoring game.  However, while I normally don't have a problem with thin themes, this one is a bit hard to get over.  You can basically play the exact same game with a normal deck of playing cards by simply removing the jokers completely and seperating out the Ace cards and using those as the "game board."  I don't think it's overpriced (especially given the lovely art), but it is a thin theme, dangerously so in my opinion.

RATING: 7

I am thankfully only too happy to step in there, so we strike something of a balance. After many plays, the game has now lost some of it's freshness. It's no longer getting played.  Had to downgrade it's rating a tad.

RATING: 9

As far as two player games go, this is one of the best! Quick set collection card game.  The concept of going on "expeditions" to each colored "region" makes it so you don't just throw down every card you have.  If you don't collect enough of one of the colors it'll cost ya!  Quick and fun - great with the wife.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.4
This is a good game to pass the time for 2 people, but I generally find it to be a bit too predictable.

The old mechanic of Rack-O is back with more attractive components.  The investment cards are what keep it a bit more interesting. The challenge is if a player gets a bad hand to start (i.e. all high cards), it can be difficult to choose a path to go with, and then he gets way behind.

"Lost Potential" would be a better name for this game.

UPDATE: After playing this quite a bit more online, I recognize that it's a decent game - the problem now is I've played Keltis, which I think is vastly superior.  LC is not bad (I'm upgrading my rating) but just not as enjoyable.  But it's small size and quick playtime are definite pluses.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Components: Beautiful oversized cards and game board for discarding.

Experience: It is short enough to be played multiple times in one sitting, the luck of the draw keeps it interesting for me, and I really enjoy the differing emotions it inspires: when I am either reluctant to give up a single card, because I'd rather wait it out and observe my opponent, or when I am eager to play out the good cards from my hand, but am unable to play them all before the draw is exhausted. I find the decisions simple, yet interesting, and the interaction benign, making Lost Cities a pleasant way to spend time with someone.

My best friend and I have ground this game down to its barest profit margin, with each of us willing to take a loss on a color rather than risk giving a potentially useful card to the opponent. Makes for very low scores.

I play with one round per game, rather than with three per game as the rules suggest.

First Played: 2002-01-01
Last Played: 2015-07-18
Plays (225):
2 players: 225
vs. robot: 3 (not included in total)

RATING: 8

What surprises me most is that the core scoring mechanics is very "mathy", but I've never seen that adversely affect anyone's opinion of it.  Tough choices abound as you balance your own investments with trying not to help the other player.  Simple play thats VERY easy to learn, this game is my wife's favorite, and one she REQUESTS to play, which is always nice.

RATING: 7
Played this one for years -- superb family choice, whether playing with spouse or with kids. For younger children I play a simple handicap technique, where I'll only look at X cards in my 8-card hand, thus narrowing my choices and discard options. I then "level" my kids up, starting low (X=2, for instance) and then take it higher and higher as they beat me, till eventually the handicap washes away... and your kids are killing you....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was a finalist for my choice of a "coloured cards with numbers" game (along with Schotten Totten).  But no, it was not to be.

I think, like Schotten Totten, that there are not enough decisions to make here.  Sure, you make some decisions on when to start an expedition, but once the cards are down you're just locked in and waiting to see whether or not you get the cards you need.  Then its just luck of the draw: will you get the cards you need, or will your opponent?  Will you get them at the right time?

I will say that I like that the game forces you to do something every turn; you can't just camp out until you get a perfect hand (like in Ticket to Ride or something).  And I also think the game is actually quite thematic.

For now, Arboretum will be my "coloured cards with numbers" game.  It has so many more tough decisions at all stages of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Having played numerous games, most of which online, I think it's fair to say that this is one of my favourite two player games. 

The rules are very simple and the luck factor is definitely there (as you draw cards and have to play one each turn), but it is certainly a game where some skill is involved. 

You try to focus on a few colours, as you pay 20 points for every colour you start. However, you don't want to show early on which colours you'll be playing, trying to entice your opponent to throw out the card you need.

I'm a fan of Knizia's work and this game is certainly one of my favourites, although Euphrate & Tigris and -to a lesser extent- Genius are also very enjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great game for unwinding and spending time with a spouse.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.97546
I think the game is 60% luck, 40% skill though Ian disagrees.

The game is all about managing your luck - considering the probability chances that you'll finish a route in the black, how likely it is that the opponent holds a certain card or will take the cards you need and the chance of you even having enough turns to play your cards.

There are also many seemingly viable strategies - do you try for 3 expeditions? Or try and make one monster expedition? Do you throw away the cards you no longer need or bluff and hope your opponent now feels free to throw away those cards you want.

When do you start your expeditions?

Despite the simple toys (with only 2 relevant properties each and an easily understood distribution) and simple rules (essentially being 'put down a card, pick up a card) i can see loads of scope for discovery.

2009-07-15 (9 plays)

I think it's probably actually more skill than I first thought (70-30?), given that I usually beat Joel ( in our adaptation) and Gregor beat me both times soundly.

I feel like I'm missing something and that gets me excited to play it again. At the same time, I just felt hopeless against Gregor. Maybe the lack of a handicap system is a possible drawback.

If he were willing though, I would have gladly carried on playing, trying to win what now appears to be a game of judging probabilities, arithmetic and psychology.

A lot deeper than I first thought and I think it could be played at different 'levels'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I really wish the cards were standard size, because it would make the game much more portable.

RATING: 6
Fun little 2-player card game of risk vs. reward.  Your goals must not be spread out over too many excavations, as there is only a limited amount of cards shared by both players.  Quick game, but drawback is it's only 2-player (well, unless you buy another copy of the game).  One mechanic I like is that you must either play OR discard a card on your turn. Your opponent can then choose to take the card you discarded.  

I also like how the game is light, small and easy to set up and plays quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is brilliant in it's blending of simple gameplay and difficult decision making.  Each turn is simply play/discard a card, and draw a card.  That's it.  BUT the difficulty comes in when you decide to actually play a card to start an expedition, because you can only play cards on that same pile of higher numerical value each later turn, and you lose points if you can't score a high enough combination in a particular color.  Then there is the added complication of seeing what your opponent is collecting or playing, and trying to make sure you don't give them easy points, while trying to make room in your hand for cards that you want as well.  I love this game, and if you want to find a good 2 player game, this is a hard one to beat for it's ease of play, and short playing time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Quick 2 player game but doesn't really do it for me
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
Lost Cities is a very fun, quick game that works well over coffee or morning breakfast. The rules are easy to teach and as long as you can multiply numbers, you can figure out this game. There is a bit of math involved with tracking points scored throughout the game. As with any game with cards, a bit of luck is involved, but strategic planning \ mathematical probability is certainly a part of this game. As with many of Reiner's games, Lost Cities has that extra layer of interest which keeps it hitting the table often. A typical game can be played in less than an hour.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[28 Mar 2017] - 6 (4 plays)
Game play consists of drawing cards from a common draw pile and then trying to create stacks of cards of increasing value to earn points. The value of a stack is 30 - (sum of the cards), so just by starting a stack you're in the hole. The strategy is pretty simple - don't start a stack unless you know you're holding a bunch of cards and try not to let your opponent know what color you're trying to stack so they discard you something that will help you. A quick filler but didn't seem to offer enough challenges for my normal liking. After 4 plays, I felt like I had experienced the game and further plays aren't necessary.

RATING: 8.2
[April 2016 - 8.2]
Fun and fast intro game that anyone can learn and similar to Battleline. It's short time frame (5-10 minutes) really creates the sense of a race and running out of time in the end. The other raw emotions come from wanting a card, waiting for a card and then giving up, only to get it the next draw. Luck plays a bigger role than in Battleline, but there's still strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a very simple, addictive game. It plays fast and you will almost always end up playing it over and over. Most of the strategy is not making the best play but in not making the worst play that will help you opponent. It is agonizing what to play at the beginning and this holds true to the very end. Set up is nil and it plays so fast that it is perfect for when you just want to knock a few games out at lunch or when waiting for something (like the other gamers to show up).

RATING: 6
[2008-09-24 Rating: n.a. -> 8]
Rating of 8 is based on a couple of online-games versus a not so strong AI at http://www.yourturnmyturn.com/. This seems to be a nice game which reminds me of Schotten Totten. The decisions are somehow similar. Sometimes you don't wanna play a card but you have to. There's a fair amount of luck involved but since the game plays fast (just like Schotten Totten) it doesn't bother me.

+ This game is just fun and plays fast
+ Some tough decisions
+ I guess my non-gamer friends will like it
+ There are definitely some "strategies"

o Price is okay for a card game (~10€)
o Just two players

- Fair amount of luck. So you can't really plan too far ahead.

RATING: 6
The theme of this game kinda matchs the overall goal of the game. In the end though it is really just a numbers game. It isn't a bad thing however thats just how I feel about it. I have a lot of fun playing even though I feel like I get put in spots where I might only have two somewhat equal options and when I pick one and three turns later the other was the better choice and its to late to fix the mistake, obviously. The more I play I feel like I can overcome this randomness in draws, but I realize even now it will probably impact my point totals at the end since I didn't risk it. 

I recently got Jambo and would almost always play that game over this one. Pretty much this is one I will get tired of playing back to back while Jambo I generally won't get tired of it.

RATING: 7
Highly enjoyable cardgame with a fair chunk of strategy and skill. Yes you can be undone without any chance of recovery if the cards go against you but that is the same with any card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.95
Each expedition is a road to the unknown and the mechanics used in this game is perfect to depict that. What you feel playing this game right away is the risk taking factor on each decision you make. It can either be one full of elation when you do make the right choices and the deck remains in your favor or full of regret when the deck turns against you. Either ways it makes you come back for more. This very simple game is easy in a lot of ways - easy to learn, easy to carry, and easy to win and easy to lose. There's also a strategic element in it that you may do to turn the tide of the game by combining your decision making skills with the cards that you're dealt with. You can even influence the other player so that he may give you favorable cards. I'd rate this game higher if they could somehow add more players into this game without ruining the mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Update:  getting a bit boring.  Really hate keeping score but seems I am only one in family who can master the Lost Cities algorithm (sad, sad)

RATING: 10
Well this is a classic! My rating is not based on the complexity of the game, which is quite low, but to the fun and replayability the game has! You finish a game and you instantly want more! The urge to keep a high red card for example and probably discard another until you re lucky enough to draw a lower red is always entertaining. Luck has definitely a role to play in this game, however, after hundrends of plays i can say that generally when luck is balanced, which is usually the case, the one with better tactical skills wins. A game that all women and non-gamers will enjoy as well!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Players are dealt 8 cards each from a deck of exploration cards. The cards consist of five suits, each representing a different destination. The cards are numbered from 2 to 10 in each suit, plus three "agreement" cards. A turn consists of play/discard a card, draw a card, but cards played must be in ascending order. Scoring is the sum of the cards in each suit minus 20, multiplied by the agreement cards. Incredibly simple, but very tense. The "one more game" factor is huge. As Mike Siggins once wrote, this is a "hobby affirming game". 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Idea & Mechanism:
Explore old ruins, play cards from 5 different colors valued 1-10 and 3 times multiplier. Your final score from each color is cards played-20*multipliers. You can only play bigger card to the pile. Discard cards to common pile where opponent can grab em and play to his piles.

See also: Battle line (I like more)

RATING: 8
Finally picked this one up, and yes, my wife does love it.  Not for the reasons I usually see given though (non-confrontational, multiplayer solitaire).  I find this game to be downright cutthroat.  Our game is focused on denying each other needed cards (only to discard the 8 the turn after they play the 9) and on bluffing them into giving up the investemnt card you want.  She loves it, and she repeatedly thumps me at it.  While I like it, overall I find Battle Line to be similar but slightly better.

RATING: 7
One of the best 2-player board game I've played.  Each player starts an expedition to 5 potential archaelogical sites.  However, the cards that will ensure success are divided among the players, so don't start a new expedition unless you think that you'll do better than your opponent.  Plays quickly and the rules are simple.

RATING: 6
Két játékosnak megfelelő mélységű taktikai csata, ahol a szerencse szerepe nem elhanyagolható. Aki ezzel együtt tud élni, annak kiváló taktikai kártyajáték. A téma viszont annyira nem jön át. Egyenlőre ez az első kétszemélyes játék, amit kipróbáltunk. Első játéknak kiváló. (2013.12.25.)

A feleségemmel ismét játszottunk egyet. A szerencse szerepe nem változott, mégis simán győzök a feleségem ellen, pedig nem rossz játékos. Tehát a jó taktikázásnak, melyik színre megyek rá, melyiket engedem el (egyáltalán nem rakok le hozzá lapot a negatív pontok elkerülése végett), melyiket blokkolom (nem rakok ki egy lapot direkt, amire az ellenfelem is vár) igenis nagy szerepe van. Nagy előnye a játéknak a rendkívül egyszerű szabály, a gyors játékmenet és a rövid előkészítési idő. Aki csak egy könnyed játékra vágyik a párjával, vagy még csak most csöppent bele a társasjátékok világába, annak egy jó játék lehet. (2015.01.23)

RATING: 9
A buddy and I after we both graduated from college and moved up to Chicago played this game A LOT. To the point that I was burnt out on it and contemplating getting rid of it. But I never did because that was a fond time. And after dozens and dozens of games it really clicked what the game was about, I felt like I was investing in an expedition hoping for that big payout at the end, but not knowing if it was there. It wasn't a game played with a five suited deck, it was much more. Then I taught it to my wife and I realized that this is a game that needs to be widely available and everyone should be playing. It is just good.

RATING: 7
Another strong pick for a short game with the wife. While I prefer Knizia's other game of a similar nature (BattleLine) for it's deeper tactics, Lost Cities brings it back to a lightness that makes the game easier to get out for a quick game.

Even with it's very math-y scoring system (which I'm a huge fan of, especially the =20 risk for starting any expedition), it's still easy to appeal to players with the art alone. The game's theme may be minimal in play, but it looks like a gradual investigation into ancient ruins.

RATING: 5
After playing this game a few times, I realized that it's nothing more than a repackaged card game with an adventure theme. An almost identical game can be played with a deck of cards using the Aces as the cities, with each suit representing the different cities. The face cards of each suit represent the multi-scores and all your left with are 2-10 cards. It's still an OK game, but seems like a waste of money when you can play the same game with a deck of cards.

RATING: 3
"In Lost Cities, another card game in the Kosmos two-player series, the object is to mount profitable expeditions to one or more of the five different lost cities."

I only give this three points in respect for the people who like this sort of thing. I am, admittedly, not a math guy. I would rather play with a calculator. Alone. In the dark.

RATING: 7.5
A terrific, fast 2-player game... one of the very best out there for what it does. Fun and addictive, the only downside to this one is that entire games can pass by in silence. It's not a very interactive game. Great look and theme. Calculating the score at the end can be a bit of a pain, and works best with a pad, pencil and calculator. 

**Addendum- I've lowered my score half a point because I find that now, a year after purchasing it, I am less inclined to want to play this one. Maybe it's because it's not very interactive, or maybe it's because I just burned out on it. Still a good game when you only have a 15 minute window, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Good, quick, deep, tense 2 player card game.  

Variable strategies. 

Dropping cards in the middle in restraining to show your hand in the early game is just as tense as changing suits in the middle and racing to finish in the end game.  

You can take risk by faking you are not going for a suite to lure cards out of your opponent or use a middle card to lure your opponent to get a card while holding hime back.

You have to watch the other player is doing on the other side.  Have not try the brutal variant of placing on the other side yet - doesn't seem like a good idea.

RATING: 7
I like the fact that it's a quick light filler card game.  "Let's include a board you don't need, and make the cards bigger to justify a higher price tag!!" is probably what was decided after the publisher put together this game.  Anywho, I like the decisions you have to make, such as, whether to hold cards that are beneficial to opponents or making room in your hand to help out your own situation.  I also like that players have partial control over how quickly the game ends.  Overall, I can see why it's so highly rated as a couples game but there are other two player card games that I just prefer.

RATING: 10
I LOVE THIS GAME!  It's hard to find good games I can convince my wife to play, and yet be complex enough in strategy that I can still enjoy it... this is that game.  Simple rules that allow for a staggering amount of incredibly difficult choices in tactics.  Loads of fun.

BTW, I've played a 4-suit version of this with a standard set of poker cards.  Lay down the aces as the "board" of color markers, use suits as the colors, all face cards count as handshakes.  Works well, even with only color "suits" to play with.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Solid game. Cool artwork and cards. A good mix of hard decisions and fast gameplay. Up to 8 after bringing it back out yet again. After a break, I've come to realize this is a near perfect balance of speed and choices. Up to 9 after my consistent return to it. It's the game I compare all other two player games to. Are there better two player games? Sure, but LC provides that perfect choices/speed/ease of play mix. 

To put as elegantly as my friend has in the past "Playing Lost Cities is just a relaxing experience." That's it. It's not overly complicated, it's not hard to play. I've never walked away utterly amazed by the game, but I've always enjoyed the experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've introduced the game to other people and they all liked it!

RATING: 7
De lo más aceptable en juegos para 2 personas.Indicado en veladas de 2 jugadores y también para veladas de muchos jugadores cuando no todos pueden jugar al mismo jagador.
Es rápido y además las cartas son de tanta calidad como belleza.
Debemos intentar empezar las menos expediciones posibles y cada una de ellas alargarlas lo más posible.Si no tenemos más de 3 cartas de una expedició o 2 muy altas no deberíamos empezarla, porque nos restará puntos al final de la partida.Debemos quedarnos en la mano las cartas que puedan beneficiar a nuestro rival.
Viciante!! estamos todo el día de revancha en revancha.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My play count for Lost Cities is way off. I must forget to record this game. It is a staple for my wife and I.

What makes Lost Cities shine? Decisions! Every turn you are challenged to play the right card. You feel you have plenty of time in the beginning, but you can't predict which cards will end up in your hand. Investing in one path may prove costly, while skipping investment in another may be a missed opportunity. Investing in all five is, of course, madness.

I would set the level of agony in each decision to a level just below Twilight Struggle or a balanced war game. The levels of depth and involvement are wildly different but the pain is the same.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 8
A very elegant and tense card "building" game.  At it's best, it requires anticipation, flexibility and risk taking.  At it's worst, it can seem a frustrating luck-fest when the cards just don't come as hoped, though this randomness is generally mitigated when several "rounds" are played out.

Overall, an outstanding game for which I don't understand all of the criticism here, and one that has become our 2-player travel game of choice.

RATING: 7.5
A fun & fast-paced card game.  It's like rummy but with a neat Knizia twist.  Players are often faced with tough choices of discarding a valuable card or sacrificing points to prevent the opponent from scoring even more.

Don't let the game's simplicity fool you!  There's a LOT of strategy to this game.  Very clever, and probably my favorite 2-player Kosmos game.  Grade: B-

RATING: 7
Sort of like a more interesting version of Rack-O, this game forces you to hold your own high cards as well as your opponent's low cards, so that only your "expeditions" are successful.  The rules are very simple, the theme is adequately integrated.  This is one of those "play 3x and accumulate scores" games.  A little bit dry, but very solid: typical Knizia!

RATING: 8
One of the two games that I will promptly take from the shelf if non-gamer friends visiting me discover my collection and ask to play something. RATING: 4
Played 30+ times.
Rating history: 7 to 6 to 5 to 6.

2000: Decent filler, good game to play with the gf.

July 2014: A numbered card game with light tactical play and nice art. Typical Knizia, there is very little theme here, but it's a tough little game that has a fair bit of tension in its short playtime. 

Belongs to the "addictive light abstract" category with Splendor and  Cribbage.


 [o-m]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a fun game that keeps you on your toes.  It's definitely good filler, particularly when played fast.  I don't really get all of the complaints about the scoring system.  It's simple addition and very light multiplication.  There are extremely clear examples in the rulebook for reference.

Admittedly, the theme is meaningless and pasted on.  The game could easily be reproduced with two decks of cards and a marker, although that's not a negative in and of itself.  It's just a super tight two player card game, like a good Rummy variant.  There are further similarities to Rummy but it's certainly its own game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Just for 2.  A beautiful game that is easy on the eyes.Always the game that goes on trips. 

I have played over 7,000 games (a game consists of 3 hands)since 5/04.  I do not have that many plays recorded here on BGG because we started playing prior to my recording plays here, but we had kept records on paper.  

Once two players are equal in strategy, it becomes more a luck-of-the-draw game, but still addicting.  This is one of the few games my non-gamer family suggests--and since I am game hungry, I never turn it down, even though I am SICK-TO-DEATH of it, but interestingly enough, not really. 

3/25/08 We just opened our 5th box, 10/1/08 opened 6th box, 6/9/09 opened 7th box, 9/5/2010 opened 8th box, 11/1/11 opened our 9th box--The cards hold up well, but the ink eventually wears off the front & back. On only 1 deck did we ever bend the cards. Looks as though we get about 700 games to a box (3 hands per game).  9/1/2017 Opened 14th box.

Highest score after 3 hands, 337 on 1/18/09; Highest score on a single color in one hand, 136 on 12/06; Most games won in a row, 11 on 5/07; The difference of most points in the lead after 3 hands, 227 on 11/05.  I lost the records for the single highest hand.  We lost interest in keeping up on these scores, especially since our playing has evolved so that we rarely get the really high scores any more.

Dispite all these games played, I have only played once with four people (combine part of a 2nd deck per rules).

RATING: 6
Ranks alongside Blokus, Bohnanza, Rumis and Ticket To Ride as one of those games I would be confident showing to absolutely anyone.  This game is all about knowing when to play your cards.  And being able to choose how many rounds you play means it can last as long or end as quickly as you want.

Still, I will almost always choose to play Dominion, San Juan, Citadels, or even Bohnanza over this when looking for a quick, two-player card game.

RATING: 4

Recommended for any gamer's library. *** UPDATE: This game is starting to hurt due to the better 2P games available now. Its decisions just aren't much fun anymore. Can do a lot better as 2P fillers go. Note though that it's still recommended for non-gaming folk, due to its simplicity and non-threateningness (is that a word?). Just don't expect it to hold you attention for long. It might, just don't expect it to. You might be disappointed.

RATING: 6.95
2016
====

What can I say about Lost Cities that hasn't already been said? I clearly have a thing for Knizia's card games with Thor and Schotten Totten already appearing on this list. There will be more from the good Doctor believe me.

[2014.06.15 - 7.75]
This is the first, and best example of, a game that has a quality that I'd like to call "beautiful tension."

[2014.11.26]
The more that I play the more I realize that it's not entirely driven by luck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost cities is the epitomy of design elegance. The principle of trying to collect sets by drawing from a deck without any possibility of manipulating those cards should be boring as hell.

By simply coming up with an ingenious way to do the scoring Knizia has made it into an interesting game with elements of luck pushing and many tactical decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played this game well over 100 times, so many I've lost count.  I play it about 4 times a week during breaks at my work.  The rules are very simple, but the strategy is not.  You are gambling on getting the cards you want later on in the game, but you may also get stuck at the beginning of the game with cards you don't want to play until later.  What's worse, you can't discard them because then your opponent can pick them up!  This is one of the few games where going first may not be a good thing (or a bad thing.)  I also love that you can draw cards from the discard later in the game to slow the game down and buy yourself time to make all the moves you want to make.  After 100's of plays, I keep coming back for more.  Another Knizia masterpiece!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

--Update:  Heh...hadn't updated this one in a while.  The comments above are hilarious when you look at the number of plays we've logged for this (and I've forgotten a few.)  This game is stupid, but fun and addictive.

It's more like a straight up card game with some funky scoring more than anything else.  But the hoi palloi thinks its okay to like this game because it's "designer".  If Parker Brothers had put this out, it'd be ranked #2719 and no one would have ever given it another look.

Recommended, all the same.
