RATING: 8.948
The pick of the crop for two player card games, with a pleasant mechanic that gives a slight angst feeling.  Going first is always a difficulty, as your never sure what to play.  Can be played a number of times and is still a most enjoyable card game when you just have a partner and not a lot of time (14/12/08). UPDATE: I have reached a point where there is nothing new or unexplored with this game.  It's now the same feeling i get when playing Euchre, in that It's obvious  what the next move should be.  I guess there are now  just other card games - will tend to save this as light filler or for newbies, so rating drop from 8 to 7 (29/11/11). UPDATE: The iPad app gave me an opportunity to reassess how good a game it is. As It's also a game the wife will actually play and enjoy, It's pretty hard to beat (and the actual big cards are lovely to hold), elevated to an appropriate 9 (9/3/13). UPDATE: Don't really get this to the table, but iOS is ok, still an excellent game (rating 8.948, Sept 16).

RATING: 8
This is a great Knizia card game that has a nifty math mechanic.  You have to take a lot of chances in this game, and I can't think of any other game that uses a mathy, push-your-luck mechanic to build tension in the same way.  I like how you have to balance your expeditions and take risks on the cards you are going to get.  Obviously there is luck involved in what cards you pull, but it is all part of the risk.  The theme could have been anything, but I like the one Knizia chose.  Great card game!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was a neat card game to play and it's one my friend would actually play with me because, well... because she could beat me at it. The game is played with cards that have Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, and White numbers on them. The idea is to lay down the cards (numbered 1 to 10) with the lowest numbers and work up to the highest. At the end of the game you subtract 20 from the total to come up with the score. You can also lay down up to 3 contract cards which become multipliers at the end. Don't do contracts though if you can't get more than 20 points out of a string of numbers. You can also get more points if you have 8 or more cards in your string of numbers. Cards you discard go on the board, so be careful dropping those down as your opponent can draw them if they're useful. Two of these games will expand into a 4 player game where you can play partners.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great two player game for couples.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Beautiful cards, and a nice quick game for 2 players with some interesting decisions. It does not however have the depth and angst with which it is often credited - there seems to be a maximum efficiency at which you can play, and most players approach that. It then becomes a game of luck where the player whose risks pay off best wins the game.

RATING: 7.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Incredibly easy to learn.  Great for non-gamers.  Tense, but not very confrontational.  Forces you to make a lot of tough decisions.  Luck - in the form of the order of the cards - is a factor, but the unpredictability of the card order is what forces these decisions and makes the game fun.  Also, luck is evened out somewhat since you effectively play the game three times to determine the winner.  I've never cursed at a game as much as this one, but that's not a bad thing - it's just funny what it brings out in people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Lost Cities is every bit as addictive as others have stated.  Quick, tense, frustrating even.  The tendancy to drop a card right before picking up the card of the same suite you had been waiting for happens more often in this game than I believe probability allows for.  A great 2-player by the good doctor.

UPDATE: Still getting played frequently.  The thrill this game offers in such a short time is astounding. Truly a classic with longevity in replayability.  Yes the game is dictated by the card draw, but not everything worth playing is ripe with multiple avenues to victory.

An excellent 2-player game.  In the early-game, you're both trying to figure out which expeditions to start while throwing off your opponent.  The late-game is about timing the end of the game to benefit your expeditions over your opponent.

RATING: 6
I really enjoy this game.  It's super fast and super easy to teach new gamers.  I managed to teach a 7 year-old student and play a game, all in a 15 minute recess.  Not only that - he independently figured out how to improve his game and where he made mistakes.  

I enjoy the luck of drawing the cards, as well as the opportunity for strategy.  I would say it's 70/30 skill/luck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I think I get what I dislike about Knizia's games as a whole: the theme often feels applied after the fact -- like he came up with a fairly abstract concept and then wall-papered it with some loose theme so as to produce an EXCITING! box write-up and make it more salable.  If you have some way of making/acquiring a 5-suit deck of cards then there's nothing in the experience here that would be lost by ditching the exploration theme.  (Well, that and the scoring.  For such a light, simple game the scoring is unneedfully complex.)

As for the game itself?  I need more plays before I decide, but right now I'm leaning towards dislike.  (The SO, on the other hand, likes it so I doubt that I'll be allowed to get rid of it.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I'm bumping up my rating slightly with more plays.  I've found the luck factor can be negated somewhat both early in the game and towards the end of the draw deck by managing your hand through careful manipulation of the Expedition discard stacks.  Very enjoyable

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Quite a fun little set collection game for two players. The card art is really nice, and there's a certain appeal to holding larger cards (Dixit, etc). 
The game is super easy to teach and play.
I would directly compare this game to Arboretum, which feels very similar, and the core of the game involves making an educated guess as to which cards your opponent is holding/going to invest in. (Arboretum does this also, but there is sort of a spatial element to it in that game.)
I love games with the simple set up this has; ALL cards shuffled, then a hand dealt to each player. (ie: Zero to minimal setup time! You're up and playing.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Great two player game for everyone. Even girlfriends like to play it. Rules are easy to learn, but underneath those 'simple' rules lies a rather deep game. You are playing your opponent even though it doesn't seem so at the beginning. It's short (10-15 mins for a game, usually three games are played in a match), doesn't occupy lots of table space and is fast paced. The minor negative point for me is that luck can and will play a role in determining the winner.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating of 7 is based on this game compared to all games in general. If rated among the filler games for 2 players, it is an 8. With more time there are better games, but this one is a very competitive quick playing game. And very little in rules to remind someone who hasn't played in a while. When playing, the decisions affect your outcome right from the start, and often players will need to choose the least bad among options since there is not a good option in the cards that turn. And at the end, how much time is left in the game is determined by the number of cards and each player's intent to either speed up or slow down the arrival of the game end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic, simple, fast and fun. Always love playing this game

RATING: 7.5
The more I play this game the more I like it. There is just something about it, that keeps pulling me back. I think it is the fact that, it's almost like golf. You can play a terrible round of golf, but if you hit just one nice shot, you relive that shot in your mind and want more of it. In Lost Cities if you don't get good cards, you make due and hope to break even, but the next round  one color could be great and you could get an 8 card expedition and dominate. Just talking about the elusive 8 card expedition makes me want to play right now! Lets go!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
One of the most hugely overrated games on the geek.  Considering it isn't rated that high, thats really saying something.  What feels like strategy is actually a lot of guessing based on your hopes that you will draw the cards you need.  The game has a luck factor that I normally am not bothered by, but with a game with this little meat on its bones, that much luck is just annoying.  Once you learn basic play concepts such as don't give your opponents cards they can use and don't play too many handshakes until you are sure you can finish off the run, then the rest of the game doesn't have a whole lot of strategy to it.  Plus, any game that requires folks to double check each other's math is usually not my thing.  Do you remember order of operations from 3rd grade math class?  OOO is involved with the scoring of this game.  This game is too complex for what it offers, and considering its pretty simple, that tells you a lot.

Update: The lost cities board game is slightly better than this from gameplay perspective, plus has better bits.  Both suck, but the original here sucks worse!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Like many BBG'ers this is a favorite of my wife.  We mis-interpreted the rules and were playing "wrong" for a long time (till the X-Box Live version made it clear).  Our version was cut-throat in that you couldn't play a card lower than the last played to EITHER side of the board.  This meant you could start an excavation having a long set of the cards, and the other person could cut you off by playing a high card.  They'd take a loss, but not as much as you did.  This resulted in a few rare (for me) occasions of real anger playing a game.  Even playing the "real" way is a fun challenge.  X-Box Live version is also very nice.

RATING: 6
Nice pictures, fun theme, if a bit pasted-on. Really a push-your-luck sort of game because you are weighing the risk that you will draw a card you need when it is too late if you play. Oddly enough, I feel this game would be improved if played without a hand limit, because you would never be forced to play a card you didn't want to and the risk would all be based on how far ahead the other player was getting. Lots of luck of the draw, only for 2 players. I hear the ladies like this one, though I'm sure you could find other games they would like better.

RATING: 8
A surprisingly clever 2-player. At first the dependence on the luck of the cards feels staggering since even making optimal plays will sometimes leave you in the hole. But after losing early games by horrible margins I realized that risks have to be taken early in the hand. Aggressive play is usually the best. Players must astutely manage card-drafting, discarding, and the draw-deck to maximize scoring. With continued play these competing demands shine.

RATING: N/A
Falkon00 2 30min
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a great 2 player game.  I have enjoyed playing with my wife on a regular basis though sometimes the game can be really swingy.  It is best enjoyed over 3 rounds to help even out the luck factor that creeps in.  However, sometimes there will be that game where one player wins by 100+ points and a couple more rounds won't change that gap.  

It would also be a good game for children of many age brackets to work on numbers and math in a fun and creative manner.  The end scoring requires multiplication and addition.  When your child is motivated by competition to find out their score its a sneaky way to get them to do math.  For younger children the art and counting the numbers along with learning what number is greater than other numbers is a good teaching tool.

I would highly recommend this as a 2 player game for couples as well as recommend it for family game night where children can be helped by their parents to enjoy the experience (even if they really aren't playing the core strategy of the game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A perfect two-player game.  The mechanics are deceptively simple.  Timing your plays can be quite the delicious agony.  Do I hold out for another doubler before I open in red?  Do I have time to get down 20 points of green before the deck runs out?  The artwork is also lovely.  Indeed, the art is what puts this game slightly above Schotten Totten for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[Initial Impression: 4]
Lost Cities clearly possesses a simple elegance, but for some reason it tends to alternately frustrate and annoy me.  The game rewards patience and can harshly punish risk-taking, and yet the obvious early plays involve some measure of risk.  It feels too much like you're just waiting to see what cards you draw and how they fit with what you already have - in that sense you are often playing more against yourself than against your opponent.  In some ways, I think a solitaire version of the game would play just as well, as much of the game involves reevaluation of your hand each turn as you discover which new cards are out of play for you.  I play more than I'd prefer because my primary gaming partner really likes it.

RATING: 6
A good, short and simple, two-player filler. Probably not something that would stand up to regular play too well but certainly a nifty game to bring out of the cupboard every now and again for a quick play between bigger games.

I haven't played this in a while as the missus really dislikes it.  Works fantastically well when both players are of a similar skill and I love how well balanced it feels - you are always presented with difficult decisions about which is the best card to play.

A definite keeper, but one that will only make infrequent appearances.

RATING: 7.25
$14.92 at thoughthammer (2/07)
---

This is a fantastic game for two.  So easy to play because once you have committed to a strategy you can pretty much just act on it for most of the round.  I haven't won a set of three games yet, but i'm sure I will soon.  Amy seems to like it alot too which is great.

I don't understand how people prefer battle line to this... Battle line is slower and much more fidgety; the extra card deck is not a nice element in battle line.

RATING: 7
I found this game to be simple, fast, and fun. There are interesting strategies that remind me of Bridge, and the 4 player variant adds an another level of excitement. That said, I am disappointed that this is essentially a 5-suit card deck, with a simple theme pasted on top; I feel ripped off. There is no feel of expeditions or of exploration--if I want that, I'll play Tikal. If I want to play this, I think I can construct my own game using two 52-card standard decks; I am essentially paying for the rules, and in this regard, this reminds me of another Kniza game: Escalation--another simple card game with a pasted-on theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's not as bad as Race For The Galaxy but I always feel like I can go on auto-pilot and ignore my opponent's play for long stretches of this game.

There are many 2-player games I'd rather play before this. I can't but help feel there's some kind of front-runner effect here. Lost Cities is popular because it is popular, sort of like how Monopoly has monopolized the non-BGG boardgame headspace. If Lost Cities were released in today's crowded marketplace I doubt it would be as popular as it is given the number of other games that are equally fun.

Also, there's something generally distasteful about card games that can essentially be played with a standard deck of cards. I realize that in some sense I'm paying for designer's "thought output" but there are hundreds, if not thousands, of public domain card games I could play instead.

There's not even a pasted on theme here, just an oversized deck of cards with fancier art on the front. Instead of buying Lost Cities for $20 you could buy a themed deck of cards (say cats or Renaissance artists) for $5 and have the same gameplay with just as much theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cannot understand the hype some people make of this. Sure it's a fast and entertaining two player game, but it cannot stand repeated play. I only play it when other people ask me to.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm not as crazy about this game as many others are, but it is a very solid and fun game.  I think it is interesting that you can draw cards from the discarded expedition piles or the draw pile.  The game evolves as a result, with unwanted expedition cards becoming more attractive due to the number and quality of the discard piles.  It is also interesting that the game can be sped up or slowed down through the use of the draw pile or discard piles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Among the very best card games for 2, although let it be said that's a pretty modest club. It's perfectly playable with only four suits, so a standard pack of cards can be used. Risk taking is the essential element in the game, you must start up to four 'expeditions' without knowing whether high value cards will come off the draw pile. As with all card games sometimes you get the cards and sometimes not, there's only so much that you can do to put yourself in a winning position. This is among my favourite of Knizia's games and much better than many standard card games for 2.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
They should rename this, "The Spouse Game." I heard various reviewers say this was the perfect game for a spouse that's just not as interested in gaming as you are. Upon hearing such a statement, I decided to put it to the test. And....SUCCESS! My wife absolutely loves this. It is a two-player card game that comes with 60 oversized cards where each player is competing to get your expeditions the most funding.

Now, the cover on the box is where the theme ends. The whole idea of investing in different expeditions...is really non-existent in the game. If you look at the cover you'll see that this is a Reiner Knizia game. So basically it's a bit of a thinky math game. But don't let that scare you away. The "math" part doesn't come in until the final scoring. 

The reason this game is so high on my list is because of the quick back-and-forth nature of the game. It does come down to luck of the draw, but there are important decisions that you have to make as well. Whether to invest in one expedition, only to have your opponent be completely stacked with all the right cards for that one. Or to take the risk and start supporting one more expedition when you know the game will be over soon
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
First played this on Dec 21, 2006.  I wasn't sure what to expect playing this for the first time and was eager to see how it worked.  Althought it's like rummy to some degree it really isn't.  This should be a fun game to play with the wife and I've now planned to get it.  There is enough luck and strategy to make this a must play.  I played with a very experienced player and made the rookie mistakes and at the same time he didn't take advantage of me when I really did a bone headed move.  The first of three sections it was clear I didn't know what I was doing.  The 2nd section I actually scored more as I played cautiously and actually had a really bad starters hand.  The 3rd section I played too fast as I thought I had the hang of it and made a few poor decisions.  Can't wait to play this at home.  It's also a good filler game taking 30 minutes or less to play.

I couldn't believe that a similar looking card game by the same hall of fame designer, Reiner Knizia could be this dull. I just wanted to put it back in the box posthaste and extricate myself from paying any further opportunity cost of not playing dramatically more enjoyable games. I will try it one or two times further, but I will not be likely asking to play Lost Cities.

RATING: 10
A 2 player masterpiece. Very simple game play with few choices with a great combination of luck and skill for such a short game. Everyone should own this!

Comparing to other games, there is hidden subtlety here. Risk management is key and figuring out how to get the most of a bad hand is what this game is all about. Luck does not play such a central role as one might think after a game or two.

RATING: 7
Really good two person game. I love the decisions early-on whether to invest in a color or not when you don't really have the right critical mass of cards for it -or- waiting, waiting, for the handshake doubler when you DO have the critical mass but they never show because they are in your opponents hand. I even love the anguish of investing in a color w/o critical mass and having your opponent do the same *groan*. It goes on and on...plus a nice variety on how you want to play the end game. If I knew of anyone else who enjoyed this as much as I do and if it didn't have such an unbelievable lame theme I think I would rate it higher.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of my first, and I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic game for two players.  Both players have a hand of 8 cards which contain numbers in 5 different colours.  Players then must place the cards in ascending order onto the table, at the end of the round if you have more than 20 total points in a colour then you score positive points, less than 20 hurts your total score.

Sounds simple enough but it's made interesting with the "Investment" cards which may be placed before any numbers of that colour, which multiply your points (positive or negative).  This adds a great risk/reward mechanic that's really fun and makes you want to play just one more round.  Highly recommend this as a nice simple game to play with your significant other, for example.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very fun 2 player game (see my Review). My wife likes to play this, a rare situation :)

RATING: 8
People keep saying this game is like two-player solitaire.  However, I think the player interaction is there, it is merely subtle.  It is very important to watch what the other player is doing and adapt your play accordingly. Reciprocally, what cards I play or choose not to play can influence the actions taken by the other player.  This allows some subtle inter-player strategies.

RATING: 7
A very light, very casual card game for two players. It’s easy to learn and a pretty fair gateway to modern European boardgames.

There’s not much to it, though.

(Apropos of nothing, the artwork on the board includes some archeological utensil that looks like a pair of tweezers. My creepily smart cat poked at them as if they were real — which makes me wonder about their true powers of imagination and abstraction. How many millennia till we’ve bred house pets that play board games with us?)

RATING: 7
My non-gaming wife really likes playing this game and she would rate it as a 9. I like it too but there are other games I would rather play. The theme is non-existant (I like well-themed games). If you like card games with an ordinary deck of cards you will really go for Lost Cities. It is fast and there is quite a lot of luck (you get this in cards). It is a game of tough decisions, often between bad and worse options. Can be very tense towards the end as you try to play all the great cards from your hand, while your opponent is trying to bring the game to an early close.

RATING: 8
Great game for non-hardcore-gamers, in that the rules are simple, there's a lot of replay value, and it's pretty quick.  This is a good one to pull out when you want to play a game but don't have a lot of time for explaining rules or setting up pieces.  There's some strategy, but there's also quite a bit of random chance in the luck of the draw, so it can be a bit frustrating at times, but overall I'd rank this as one of my all-time favorite games.

RATING: 8
Essentially a traditional-style card game with 5 suits rather than 4. The board isn't really needed and the cards are too large. However, it is a very well-designed game and maintains interest despite the simple rules. It can be very tense at the beginning as you decide whether to start expeditions, and requires some planning towards the end to ensure the most effective use of your remaining opportunities to add cards. There is only a modest amount of interaction between the two players.

RATING: 8
A classic two player game that deserves its reputation. A little ‘mathiness’ may creep in, especially when planning end strategies. However, it is quick playing, supports light strategy, doesn’t kill table-talk and a great game for sticking in a rucksack when out and about.

RATING: 7.25
Simple mechanics, tough choices, and no theme in true Knizia fashion. This and other Kosmos 2P games like Jambo are what helped my wife and I discover how much we loved gaming together. I don't love it as much anymore and would have traded it away by now except for the little known 4 player variant. If you combine 2 games you can play 2 vs 2! It is even better than the normal version because there is a new team element. Hidden information means you have to guess what your teammate has and what he wants you to do. Great game for non-gamer couples. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What a great card game! It requires some good strategy, has a good theme, and requires a little luck (as in most card games). It's relatively quick and very easy to teach. The start of the game can be downright torturous as you decide to start expeditions and then immediately draw the card you'd have preferred to start with! There a nice balance betwen getitng the cards you need and holding back the cards your opponent needs.

RATING: 8
Lost Cities is a fantastic two-player game. It's very portable and accessible with interesting card art. The theme is a bit weak and luck can play a non-trivial factor in determining the winner, but the agony in deciding whether to chase cards while possibly opening up better moves to one's opponent is exciting. It's a definite keeper in my collection.

RATING: 5
Like playing 3 hands of poker with no money.  Gives the illusion of depth on top of a level of randomness that can't be overcome by card counting over 3 games.  A good player will win more in the long run, but each individual game is largely a rote exercise, with the only difficult decisions occurring when every option you can possibly take is bad.  The rest of the game plays itself.

My bet is that in 1000 plays, a good player beats an average player 550-600 times at most.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
2013-05-16

Initial Rating: 6.5

At last I got to play the fabled Lost Cities game. I had my doubts because Knizia is very hit or miss (mostly miss) with me, but at the end I liked the game. It is a light quick game (as expected) but it has some depth in it. The game can be explained under 5 minutes and played under 30 minutes. I vastly prefer this than Keltis due to the number of players. The game components are adequate, the cards are bigger than normal but I found sleeves for them so no troubles there, the art is ok too. The game has a healthy dose of luck but as it plays so quickly I don’t mind.

For me, it is very reminiscent of Battle Line (Schotten-Totten) 

In conclusion, Lost Cities is a good familiar game, I will be playing it in the future but not very often.

Current Rating: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 - Good game, usually willing to play ('Geek Definition of a 7).

I've spread this one around faster than a sailor on leave; it burns and it itches and soon everyone's got it.

It makes a great rainy day/cabin game to break out. This is a good game for playing as a filler now and again (I don't believe in playing a game to death, I like variety).  I totally stink at it and netted a -27 points in my first time out. I like it and it's enjoyable to me. Perhaps I'm too relaxed playing it though, as I've yet to make a good appearannce in it! :o) This is a very good game to introduce and has been popular with many of the women/friends that I've broken it out with. The scoring kind of scared me off at first since I'm a math-phobic person, but it was an unfounded fear; the scoring sure makes the game what it is and is important to getting a strategy for playing. I found good interaction with the opponent and you can influence their game by what you do. This game can be played with four players (2 per team, no talking!) if you have two sets together. I would reccommend this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Playing several rounds seems a good way to overcome the impact of a particularly favorable card shuffle.

RATING: 5
I once gave this an &quot;8&quot;, until playing it repeatedly with a friend.  The scores were never close, and were obviously the result of the &quot;luck of the draw.&quot;  First, I would get a crushing score, then he would.  

And before you tell me that we just &quot;don&#039;t get it.&quot;  Bull.  Both of us know how to play rummy (and are quite good at it), which is just what this is with a couple of tweaks.
Gin, Rummy, Cribbage, etc.  are all similar (in terms of being luck determinate given relatively equal skill levels), and cost a whopping $2 in quality playing cards.

RATING: 8
[>5 plays] A well-designed light game. There is a fair amount of randomness, but good play usually helps to overcome the effect of bad draws. Be careful of how many cards are left, as you often have to draw "bad" cards to extend the game long enough for you to play what you need. It deserves it reputation as a couples' game, as it's a good game to finish off a night while enjoying being together.

[u]METRICS THAT DON'T NECESSARILY AFFECT OVERALL RATING[/u]:
Weight: (Very light) :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Very Heavy)
Conflict: (No Conflict) :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Conflict)
Luck v. Strategy: (Luck-Heavy) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Purely Strategy)
Theme: (Abstract) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Theme)
Interaction: (Little Interaction) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Interaction)
Learning Curve: (Easy to learn) :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Hard to learn)

[u]METRICS THAT MAY AFFECT OVERALL RATING[/u]:
Component Quality: (Cheapish bits) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (Awesome bits)
Fun Factor: (I think it's no fun) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (I think it's LOTS of fun)
Value for the Money: (A waste) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (Worth it)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Totalmente sobrevalorado.

Este juego es simple y sin sentido. Realmente no entiendo cómo puede estar colocado en el top 200. Sólo robas cartas y tratas de ponerlas en la mesa, pero no haces nada más, no hay más opciones. Cuando acaba una ronda tienes que calcular tus puntos, y es bastante aburrido.

No es un buen juego, si quieres un juego de cartas para dos, rápido y realmente bueno, mejor Battleline.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2010
[/color][color=blue]
Totally overrated.

This game is simple and pointless. I really don't understand how it can be placed at top 200. You only draw cards and try to put them on the table, but you can't do anything more, there are no other options. When a round ends, you have to calculate your points and it is quite boring.

Not a good game, if you want a fast and really good cardgame for two people, go for Battleline.[/color]

RATING: 7
Wonderful Knizia creation which packs a whole lot of game and fun in very few rules.  Simple in the extreme but captivating in gameplay.  Although this really is an abstract game, the theme is still present - you feel like you are embarking on a risky expedition when you play your first cards.  Knizia is the short game king.  This and Lord Of The Rings: The Confrontation are genius.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost Cities is a solid game in the very simple & fast card game category. But that's all it is. It's neither exciting nor deep, and it is strictly inferior to Battle Line. I don't understand why Lost Cities is such a universal recommendation on BGG. If you're expecting a novel Euro game, you'll be very disappointed - this is a traditional card game in a very overproduced costume.

Some short 2-player card games which are superior to Lost Cities:
Battle Line (aka Schotten Totten)
Cribbage
Dominion
Jambo
Razzia!
San Juan

RATING: 8

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Nice, light two-player fare. There are some decisions to be made here, chiefly (a) how long to wait (or how long is too long to have waited) to start a new "suit" and (b) how to manage the pace of the game through picking up discards vs. drawing from the draw deck. It's fast enough to play three rounds (the recommended) in under an hour, and no one feels too challenged (except maybe by the arithmetic if it gets too late). The cards are lovely but oversized and black edged; mine already show numerous nicks after only a few plays (not enough to "tip" but still irritating). There are much worse ways to spend 30-45 minutes, but there are better ways, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
- 2 player
- Weight: Very Light
- Genre: Card Drafting/Strategy
- Length: Short

A quick 2-player card game with surprising amounts of depth. This game creates a constant inner struggle that makes for a fun experience. You'll constantly be asking yourself, "Is it too late to lay down these cards? I could lose a lot of points but I could also win a lot." or "How much does my opponent want this card? If I give it up I can get that card which would help me." There's a lot of give and take so only a discerning player, with a bit of luck, will come out the winner. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

失落的城市 - Chinese edition (2010)

RATING: 7.5
二人用のゲームではコロレットよりも面白いと思う。ただし、最後の点数計算が面倒だけど。シリーズのケルトよりもこちらがテーマがしっくりくるので好み。
遺跡探検といったテーマが好みなので甘目の点数かもしれない。が、ソロゲーム用ルールがBGGのヴァリアントで紹介されており、結構面白いので点数はこれ位。
「出したくないけど出さないといけない」が、捨て山の使い方や方針転換のタイミングを学習すれば、それほど厳しいゲームではない(?)かも知れない。
カードゲームなのに値段が高いのが欠点かな。

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This is a glorified Texas Hold 'Em card game, but nerdified so nerds would be interested and buy specialized decks. That doesn't mean it's a bad game ... just that single playthroughs will give much more noise than signal as far as who actually played the better game. (This is a common theme in many of Knizia's games and Knizia's response is to ... have them play poker-style, with multiple games that make one big game.) If one wants to play poker that's fine - but I fear very few people will buy Lost Cities thinking it will be more like Dominion than Texas Hold 'Em.

Lost Cities has a transparent theme (it's very possible to not get any flavor of it at all during the game) and is utterly overmanufactured. At its heart this game is a half-deck of cards that could be _easily_ homemade for $2. But to make it sell for $20 it has to be put into a much larger box than is needed and given a completely unnecessary board. Lost Cities may not be the only overmanufactured game out there but it is the most flagrant offender of efficiency out there. Curiously enough Knizia's "Poison" is the other game that comes to mind. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lost Cities works well as a short, friendly game, especially if you're playing with someone you love who doesn't love games.  It lacks strategic depth for me, in that the only two substantive strategic decisions comes from either assessing the likelihood of the points one can return on the base investment of any expedition, or controlling the game clock by choosing to draw from the deck of the discarded expedition cards.  That being said, it's an enjoyable game, with some quality art assets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An entertaining card game with fast playing hands which always involve the challenging decision of what suits to pursue or discard vs. when to play them to your advantage and your opponents disadvantage.  I'll gladly play this but don't see any reason to own it unless I have a regular opponent who speciifically and regularly requested this game (i.e. read wife/girlfriend).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A nice card based around melds and drawing from discards, somewhat similar to Canasta, with a spin around the five separate discard piles and the “investment” cards used to bet on making your melds. Like any card drawing game there is luck in the fall of the cards.

The rules are easy to learn, it plays quickly and you can vary the game length by the number of rounds played.

The artwork is nice, though the theme is essentially pasted on the basic mathematical game.

Four player works well too.

RATING: 6
I admit it, I am just not a big Knizia fan. I've played Ingenious, Samurai and Lost Cities and while I can see that they are well designed I just don't end up with that longing to get them to the table. The gameplay in Lost Cities is fine, especially with the interactive discard piles shared by the players, but it all just feels like a math puzzle. I enjoy a good math puzzle, but in my games I want something more. For my money, Parade and Jaipur are both much better games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As with so many couples, it seems, this is a game my wife routinely wins when she plays me. I can beat others, they can beat her, but when we sit down and face each other across this board, it's a miracle if I win a single round. If there is something about this game that she knows and I don't, she keeps it hidden pretty well. I fight the urge to play cards in all 5 colors- every hand, one color gets dismissed from my plans early in the game, only for a bright shiny combination of 2 and 3 or 6 and 8 to be dangled in front of me, and I bite. It almost never works. Too often, I also string out the game by picking up discards in order to buy time to play all the cards from my hand that I want, and in doing so, give my wife the chance to also clear hand of her cards. And it always works to her advantage. One of us married a mule-headed idiot, and it wasn't me- I have more sense than that...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost cities is one of those games that could almost be played with a traditional deck of cards. Which implies the theme is completely irrelevant. The cards are pretty, though.

What we have here is a quick and friendly card game with a wide appealing potential thanks to its extremely simple rules. The game mechanisms are clever, so it isn't only about playing your cards randomly, but luck has quite an impact.

This isn't something I'm going to play time and time again, but I will look for it when trying to introduce new people to the hobby.

Rating: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 6.5
Initially, I regarded this as perhaps a subsitute for Hearts or Gin Rummy, but not a game to play it on a real games day. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[size=12][b]Top 200 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Lost Cities:[/b][/size]
+ The game is easy to teach.
+ The game is short.
+ The theme does not bother me (it is in the background)
+ The game requires decisions to win
+ There is high player involvement
+ The replayability seems alright

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Lost Cities:[/b][/size]
- I am not the biggest fan of pure set collection games or pure card drafting games and this barely passes the line by combining the two mechanics. 
- The game plays too much like a traditional card game

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Sometimes willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 7
Quick colorful game that's easy to learn but difficult to master. And of course, there's the element of luck - get a hand full of 8s, 9s and 10s all of different colors at the start and that's that. If you discard them, your opponent grabs them, if you play them, you're likely to get minus points. Looks like this is another game I'm not going to win often, but fun nevertheless.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a stunning 2 player game as well as being a stunningly simple 2 player game.

Play colour matched cards in an incrimental order. Simple, hey? But with the hand limit and the inability to pass this game is all about blocking and ducking. Planning probabilities several turns ahead to keep a fresh supply of cards cycling in your hand so you can afford to wait on a high numbered card that you need.

This is a classic of simple rules that lead to arduous decisions.

RATING: 9
Fun card game. Scoring can be very confusing at first, and it's hard to explain how it works sometimes for new players. The card have nice artwork (like all Rio Grande/HIG produced games!). Before Lost Cities, I bought Ceasar and Cleopatra which is a relative of this game. However, I still don't get how to play Caesar and Cleopatra! Lost Cities is an easier version, and I heard Hera and Zeus is more difficult than C-and-C. Overall, this game plays quick, is a great time killer and very portable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I had a comment dating back to an (estimated) 2005, so clearly it needed updating.  I said that I didn't play two-player games enough to value this.  That's now a load of crap, as I mostly play games with my wife now, and I still don't see this as something I'd be into.  It's too dry and mathy without the charm of something a little more involved (cf. Through the Desert, Samurai, Ricochet Robots, all of which I love), and not thematically rich enough to warrant buying in game form (cf. Odin's Ravens, which you could also make a deck of, but it would be ugly and not as fun).

It's just not my thing.  For two-player card games, I'd pick several Decktet games over this.

RATING: 6

Unfortunately there are a lot of luck involved and the game is interesting only at the beginning of each round. Updated 2008: Lost Cities the Boardgame makes this one even better, so you don't really need to get this original cardgame version at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In Lost Cities, a card game from the Kosmos two-player series, the object is to mount profitable expeditions to one or more of the five different lost cities. Card play is straightforward, with a few agonizing moments sprinkled through what is mostly a fast-moving game. If you start a given expedition, you'd better make some progress in it, or it'll score you negative points. If you can make a lot of progress, you'll score quite well. After three rounds, the highest total score takes the day.Rules are included for a four-player team game that requires two copies to play.

RATING: 8
I know people rant about this being like Racko, but I actually like Racko. There's something about putting things in order that will either satisfy your OCD or send you over the edge. I like this because it's got that Racko-ness but what you discard is way more important here. The stress of not wanting to help your opponent is a great mechanic to me. The game looks fantastic and it's one of those where you feel a sense of completion when you are done. Yes, there is a lot of luck, but it's a quick game so getting that negative score once in awhile doesn't make you want to kick puppies.

I printed my own 4 player set, using cards as the central board and it makes the game much more compact and easier to transport.

By thinking about it, again this game feels very mathematic with no feeling and experience. 

On my point of view there is no interest to discard non-dead card even if other people said there is sometime a strategy in doing it.

So either I don't grasp the strategy of the game or I don't want to start calculating how much point I am going to get.

RATING: 8
Csak a netes változatával játszottam, de nem tudom elképzelni, hogy mitől lenne ez egy 7 pont feletti játék az átlag szerint. Oké, egyszerű, pillanatok alatt megtanulható, ez nyilván előny. De utána? Annyira mechanikus az egész! Szökőévente egyszer kerülök döntési helyzetbe, egyébként mindig egyértelműen adott, hogy mit érdemes cselekedni, és ezzel az a baj, hogy nem én irányítom a játékot, hanem az irányítja magát, felhasználva engem, mint sima laplerakó robotot. A játékosok sincsenek hatással egymásra, több játékonként jött csak elő egyszer, hogy érdemes volt felhúznom a másik által kidobott valamelyik lapot, vagy neki az enyémet. Ez így szinte nulla interakció, de nem ez a legfőbb baj a játékkal, hanem amit írtam: mindig könnyedén eldönthető, hogy melyik lapot érdemes lerakni, és így a játékos egyszerű statisztává degradálódik...

Update:
Adtam neki egy nagy esélyt: megvásároltam most, hogy leakciózták rendesen. És bejött! Furcsa, de most érzek igazi döntési helyzetet szinte minden játék alatt, sőt, elég sokszor, már-már folyamatosan, de amikor meg úgy jön ki, hogy egyértelmű mit kell raknom (mert mondjuk van valamelyik színből 7-8-9-10-esem, és sorban rakhatom le őket), az meg szimplán jó érzés, hogy összejött a dolog. Szóval nekem most nagyon bejön ez a játék, határozottan szívesen játszom vele, alig várom, hogy mikor vesszük elő ismét!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
First, I should say I have a bias against these types of games:  I just don't believe in fobbing off a re-themed poker deck as a proprietary game.  You could easily play this with a standard 52-card pack, since I don't believe a fifth suit adds much to this.

But what of "aesthetics"?  Well, I don't much care to look at the same 5 drawings shifted slightly to the right 9 different times.  And actually, the large size of the cards makes them hard to shuffle and annoying.

As for the game itself, well, let's just say it doesn't make my face go flush with excitement.  It plays a bit like gin.  Hardly any player interaction, the charge of "two-handed solitaire" is not far off.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A quick, fun and luck-of-the-draw based card game about exploration. The game comes with discard pile board and a pile of cards in five colors. Your job is to make expeditions that are more "profitable" than your opponents. Usually you play three rounds and who has more points at the end wins. The game is very easy to learn, and has depth to it even though it relies on luck to an extent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Another very tense Knizia game for two players. The role of luck is significant in Lost cities and you'll need to fight very hard to manage your hand and not give any points to your opponent. Most of all, you absolutely need to avoid taking any negative points by not putting any color down before you are confident you can break the 20 points barrier. Although the theme feels a little bit contrived, the cards are beautiful and more than justify it.

RATING: 8
After playing Lost Cities for the first time, I was unimpressed. Where was the game? Thinking I had missed something I headed online and came across BGG where I found two things. First, I found we had missed a rule where the players could pick up each other's discards. This was HUGE! It meant that the players could delay or speed up the endgame.

The second thing was BGG itself. I've probably spent too much time here over the last few years, but it has been worth it!

---
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/15600/item/284752#item284752]online resources[/url]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is one of the premier couples games.  We've had sort of a love-hate relationship with this game.  At first, it was a hit and we played it over and over again.  However, the addiction slowly went away and we became very burned out on it as it became almost "solved"---we were starting to play it just on autopilot, with no meaningful decisions anymore.  It stayed on the shelf for a long time.  We recently tried it out again and remembered why we liked it in the first place.  I think the time away made us shake up our gameplay and make it fresh again. It's now become our "aiport" game---a good, small and portable game that we can take out at a stressful place like the airport.

[GAMEID=50] has simple, but not necessarily obvious decisions, and coupled with its short length makes it easy to get addicted to.  It's a tight game and you have to constantly be mindful of what your opponent is doing---ultimately, you have to either keep a card for yourself or give it to your opponent.  It also taps into the risk management/gambling portion of the brain---can I afford to discard or play this card now?  Or can I afford to wait?  You can also control the game tempo by drawing from the discard or draw piles, which is a unique aspect compared to most card games.  It probably has one of the highest enjoyment to complexity ratio of almost any game we've played.  The fact that you could play it with a standard deck of cards gives it an almost classic feel, although the oversized cards and nice artwork of the real game make it worth it for us.  

Session Reports:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/336871]Lost Cities Revisited[/url]

RATING: 6
For me this game is a classic 'Emperors New Clothes' game.  The positives are that the designer Knizia once again gives the game enough material so it doesn't completely embarrass itself in public. However, for me what there is is still unappealing to the eye.  Where there is strategy it is all too apparent after the first few games leading to many subsequent games feeling the same.  Furthermore, it appears to me as a game where the 2 player Kosmos brand came first (which is the only reason I can explain the presence of the board - to justify the box size -and the price of the game).

Knizia is a prolific game designer I admire so much however I cant like all his games.  As a mathmatician this game would be a useful tool to teach kids the basics of math.  Frustrating thing is my brother and his girlfriend love this game ... argghh, cant anyone see there is nothing there.

Try Shotten Totten as an alternative to Lost Cities and never go back.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Gives a similar feel to Battleline in that both are clever, elegant, basically themeless 2 player games and you have to watch what your opponent plays carefully in your hand management schemes, holding on to cards your opponent needs just long enough so they mess up their tableau, whilst sometimes wanting to skip your own turn to prevent playing a card that opens up non detrimental card plays for your opponent. While I might have some bias towards this over Battleline because I seem to understand how to play it better, some aspects I like over Battleline are the card counting is much more transparent since each color will be in a single column/pile, there's a bit of a risk aspect with the multiplier cards, and I prefer the interaction of hate drafting my moment/stealing their discarded cards over the I play a better set than you that is in Battleline. It doesn't have the special cards that Battleline has, butthose cards always felt a little too tacked on for my taste.

EDIT: I haven't gotten a chance to play this again, but for thought I'd comment why I like it more than Arboretum. I much prefer hate drafting in a 2 player game than with more, and Arboretum seems geared best for 4 players. Lost Cities also while having a strong memory aspect doesn't seem as dependent as Aroboretum, where you can go all or nothing if you play too many cards of a color instead of holding them into your hand. Finally, the hand management and needing to hold on to certain cards in Lost Cities has more of an ebb and flow in it, as in once your opponent plays e.g. a 6 blue you no longer have to hold onto 5 blue or below, whereas Arboretum it feels more like you are in a straitjacket the whole game holding onto cards to score/deny opponents from scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Well, this one turned out fantastic!  My friends and I really like it.  Easy to teach, considerable strategy element.  Risk-taking mechanisms.  Play can be frustrating because you'll be put in situations where it's hard to not make a "bad" move, so you're always seeking the greater good -- but, that's a good kind of frustrating.  It's been a blast.  Definitely plays up the difference between a "two player game" and a "game that can be played with two people."

The cards are of a similar finish to Magic cards or Citadels cards, so they start to get the white nicks all around the edge, because you shuffle them a lot.  And, since they're oddly sized (large), protectors would be tough to come by.

Game play can be as short or long as you want, which is nice.

RATING: 8
One night my husband mentioned how he wanted to play a card game....but not necessarily rummy or euchre which was more typical for us.  Since having kids we really  stopped playing games completely so this immediately sounded like a great idea!  We looked around and found a deck of cards which turned out not to be complete so we didn't get to play anything that night.  Later on I got online and looked for a quick card game on Amazon that wasn't played with a deck of cards and this is what I came up with.  The reviews were fantastic so I bought it and since then have never looked back to typical style card or board games.  My husband and I love this game and still play it almost a year later.  This is a fantastic quick playing card game that has great card art and is quite addictive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Lost Cities: The Board Game is a far superior game. Strategy in this game involves, where possible, withholding cards the opponent needs, limiting expeditions to those one is confident of turning profitable, and only playing the handshake cards when you have a certainty of turning profitable. Unfortunately, there's a lot of guesswork and luck, and the game is short enough that there's little opportunity to mitigate the luck.

I would almost always choose to play Jaipur over this, which is another 2-player card game with similar feel and play time, but overall better execution.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another great game from Knizia. Similar in some ways to Battle Line - managing multiple "battles" simultaneously. Not quite as addictive as that game, but very enjoyable just the same. I love trying to figure out when best to start an expedition - do you wait for bonus cards or just plunge in. The "cost" of starting an expedition really flavors your decisions. It's also fun to suddenly dig into a discard pile and start a new expedition that your opponent thought would never happen. My only complaint is that it is pretty tedious to score.

RATING: 6
While I do enjoy this game, I think it just isn't the sort of game that is made for me.  For one thing, the "theme" is nonexistent.  At no point do you ever really feel like you're on an "expedition" as much as you're counting up numbers.  In other words, this is a quite literally a card game, and could be played with only slight modification to a standard deck of cards.  So, on the downside, I've always hated card games.  On the plus side, this is the best card game I've ever played and if there isn't anything better around you could talk me into a game and we'd have fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Decent 2 player game - where you have 5 colors with cards numbered 1-10 and you decide to place or pass.  If you place a color, you stack the cards in order from 1-10 betting that you'll be able to get cards that total more than 20 (over that and you gain points, less than that and you lose points).  The fun is in balancing what cards you keep in hand, deciding if you can hold off and wait to play a high card later, or keeping it in your hand to avoid your opponents from getting it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great couple's game. Simple rules. Non-aggressive. Can be played lightly, but affords opportunity for serious tactics. 

Like other Knizia games, Lost Cities reveals its charms slowly. At first, it seems too simple, too mathy. It's just putting cards in order, right? Then you get to the end of the deck and you haven't played the cards you wanted, needed to play. You curse yourself and the game and deal the cards again. Before long, you're learning when to risk and getting hooked on the payoff.

Even after you get tired of Lost Cities, you'll come back to it. It's just so simple, just so easy to jump into again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's a fun little thinker, watching your opponents played cards and considering the likelihood of other cards coming up before you start expeditions.  If you're looking to add a fun little 2-player game to your collection, this is a good one.  Once you learn it, you can see how you can play with face cards if you cut down the expeditions (suits) from 5 to 4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think strategic element of this game is overvalued. There is agonies here, but no real decision. This agonies make some illusion of strategy, but in fact whether your plan succeed or fail is almost entirely depending on your luck of draw. E.g., throwing away blue 2 and 6 would be good or bad? Bad if you get blue 8 and 9 later and good if you don't. And it is just a matter of luck.

Above said, I don't mind playing this 'cause it is very short and light.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Super simple game that just has this unnecessarily complex scoring system. When I played this with my SO we ended up counting the number of expeditions we win and who won the most, won the game. It's way better to count that way instead of the pen and paper, because I'm not a number autist who remembers them. A gateway game; sure. Pass the time while drinking coffee in the morning; maybe. Playing against other hobbyists; even Zombie Dice is better.

RATING: 8
A simple 2-player card game with a surpising amount of depth. Play a card, take a card. You are trying to make runs of cards that represent expeditions. You must make sure each expedition you begin (there are 5 available) has cards adding to at least 20 before the draw pile runs out.

RATING: 9
Lost Cities lives up to the hype. Classic Knizia minimalism and brutal, yet beautiful, math married to a fun theme and gorgeous components. I can see why some might call this game over-produced: It doesn't NEED a board, nor oversized cards, nor different artwork on every card.

...But man does it benefit from all of the above! The strategy, tactics, and subtleties here would make it a great game as just a pack of cards, but the extra mile makes it something special.

Fun, quick, and makes me want to come back for more.

RATING: 8
Really solid game. My wife and I really enjoy it. The only problem I have is that the game feels too tense in the beginning. It's a weird problem to have, but I get the feeling every time I play. I feel like I have too much to do at the beginning, and not enough information to know how to do it. Like my success in the game is determined too much by the cards I randomly draw. It's a weird feeling, how it's really tense in the beginning, but lessens as the game goes on, and you know more information about the game state.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Propiedad del club
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Some highlights of other commentors:
Easy to play
Quick game
Skill required, but doesn’t have to be a brain cruncher
High replayability
Tension over when to hold ‘em, when to discard ‘em
A bit of luck involved (sometimes too much)
Theme is thin

My thoughts:
Agree with all above, and in addition: 
I find really no theme
I found the cards to be physically too large (though great artwork)
Too much luck on opening hand

For new players I would suggest playing 3 hands immediately, without thinking. You really need to get a feel for when the game ends. That’s really the key – how many cards you will really ever play, the average numbers, the average total in a suit, and average suits to even try. From that you see how the card counting comes into play, when/how to discard, and finally the usefulness of the multiplier cards. 

Though I believe opening hands can dominate, I think the 3 rounds per game helps balance that out. 

All in all a fun game, and probably the best 2 player game because the variation each hand is great, it’s not a backstabber, and with a high luck factor sheer brilliance will not dominate. But I guess the same could be said for Yahtzee actually. Definitely high on the spouse game listings.

RATING: 6
Initially, both my wife and I found this game rather dull. It seemed like multiplayer solitaire. However, after playing with a friend I realised how this game is meant to be played. It's a fast-paced game of hand management. At every turn you have to make a decision about which card you play or discard and which ones you hold onto. Once the other player thinks along the same lines, the game becomes very interesting.

RATING: 6.5
This is a very simple card game. It's a better game toward the end where you can be faced with some tough choices, but the beginning can be hampered by the first deal. It feels limited, then opens up as cards come into play... and the deck always seems to run out just before you've played that vital 10. 

The theme is quite fun, but it could be anything, really. In fact, if you had a 6-suit card deck, you could drop one deck, lose the aces and use the face cards as handshake/deal cards and have the same game. Like all the Knizia's I've played, the theme seems an afterthought.
 
A good game, but not great.

RATING: 7
Initially this game's biggest attraction was that magical combination of reasonably good fun with price, accessibility, and speed of play. As my wife and I play this one more, however, I am enjoying the way the simplicity of the game allows us to bluff and subsequently trap one another by discarding non-intuitive cards. Adding this bluffing has created a tension between being aggressive vs overly cautious as the other player can lure, confuse, and ultimately trap the other at the end of the deck. She keeps telling me that none of that exists... but could that be metagame?  A great game, and I don't see either of us feeling like matches have become mindless or vanilla for some time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Easy deck-building two-player card game that easily can be house-ruled adjusted to accommodate three players. Basically a normal card game with custom deck and could actually be played with normal card decks. Elegant rule twists in that (1) playing a colour commits to it in that all starts out at negative score witch must be overcome, and (2) players can play multiplier cards that incrementally increase the risk and reward potential before playing value cards. Good balance between luck and skill, but tending slightly toward luck. Good and quick card game for playing with less strategically inclined people, gamers or casual alike, or in relaxed and less invested situations.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Light, compact, and quick. A great card game with a nice exploration theme. At first this seems to be a vary solitary game; however, it is important to watch the cards that the other player has discarded or played so one can predict which expeditions will be worth investing in. First time that I played this with my girlfriend we both had negative scores. Now we keep track of our scores from game to game, trying to outdo ourselves.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Game in a Nutshell: Choose to invest, starting out in the negative, in some of five different areas and then try to earn more points then your opponent by doing a better job of making up those points by playing numbered cards in your investments.

Played as: 2 player.

Pros: A much welcomed change of pace from the more traditional rummy style card games that dominate the casual market. Interactive in a non cut-throat way. Easy to learn and plays fast enough that you can lose count of how many times played. Takes almost no effort to find a partner to play a couple quick hands.

Cons: There's no beating bad luck, though it's a minor complaint given games short length (It's wearing more as time goes on). In addition to being easy to find an opponent, it's also easy to burn out on this game when it gets requested a lot.

Other: This is a good game, but a word of advice: play in moderation.  Most likely you'll be playing this game a lot so try and stretch out time between plays in order to keep it fresh. It's one of the last games I'd like to play at the moment due to burn-out.

Best Use: Two-player gateway-game or time killer with the casual types.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A simple yet fun game. I feel there is a lot of tension in trying to decide what cards your opponent has and what risk there is in attempting a specific expedition. I could see this game getting a limited number of plays though just because it's still just a filler and there really isn't a lot of variability, though the manipulation of your opponent and attempting to predict them I feel makes up for this.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After ~20 plays.  Not much love here.  I respect it for the fact that there is a real psychological game that emerges: you can manipulate your oponent by playing discards that lead him to incorrect inferences about what you are trying to do with your cards, and about what he can do with his.  To be really good you can't just compute probabilities.  Still, respect isn't the same thing as affection, which is maybe odd because I love psychological games.  Perhaps it's because this suffers because this is a similar kind of psychological game that lord of the rings: the confrontation is.  The latter is one of my favorite games and infinitely richer than lost cities, so I have little reason to bother with lostcities.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I played this while at a game store waiting for some games to finish up.  The owner of the store taught my sister and I how to play.  We both quickly picked up the game and we were flying through by our third play.  The only real strategy in this game is to make sure not to discard a card your opponent needs, and that is usually pretty easy to do.  After that it is all luck of the draw.

The point to this game is that there are several lost cities you are trying to find.  You don't have to go in search of all of them, but you want to make sure you can get down the path quite a ways before the end because there are costs to starting the expedition.  Playing your cards in the different colors is how you move closer to the lost city.  Each card you play must be equal to, or higher, than the previous card in that color.  The scoring is hard to remember, especially so many years after playing, but the first few cards leave you with negative points, but after going far enough you start making positive points.

This game just has too much luck, and really little to no thought involved.  I have heard this game touted as a game even your girlfriend will play, in my book that is just another way to say this game is so simple that it isn't worth your time.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 2

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably one of my favorite quick 2-player games of all time. There is light-strategy to the game, as well as a lot of risk and luck.

It's fairly straight-forward in terms of rules. Both players start with 8 cards. In the middle of each player is a board with 5 different expeditions they can go on. You can only play a 'Handshake' card at the start of an expedition, hence the risk. The reward and luck to the 'Handshake' cards comes in the fact that they multiply the points received each time (eg. 1 'Handshake' = 2x total score, 2 'Handshake' cards = 3x total score, etc.).

The players play 'against' each other, but on separate sides of the board. You then can only play a higher number than the card played before, so if you play a "5", you cannot place a "4" or less on top of it.

Each expedition costs 20 to go on, so you are automatically -20 in the hole. Therefore, you want to try to at least score 20 on each expedition to break even, with the hopes of scoring more.

I recommend to the boyfriends/girlfriends and spouses out there. An easy game to pick up, and a lot of fun to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Part of the far-reaching "Great Knizia Purge of 2014," this felt less like a purge and more of an exorcism for my collection.  I had long kept it in the hopes that it would grow on me but even as a solo game (where I had no one to blame for my rotten card-drawing luck) I still could not contain my disdain for this title.  Good riddance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
US
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good combination of strategy (which colors to play, where to draw cards from), luck (which cards are dealt to you), and player interaction (which cards to discard, as your opponent can pick up cards you discard).  This has the possibility for lots of thought to go into each move, with much strategy, yet the options are not overwhelming.  Almost all the information you need is visible in front of you at all times, and thus even though this is a card-based game there is virtually no card counting required (yay!).   This seems like this should have great replayability, especially given how relatively quick it is.

RATING: 9

One of the best 2 player games in my opinion.

RATING: 8
I had my doubts about this game at first but it was all erased after we played it. Beautiful looking cards and simple yet strategic game play. Players head up expeditions to one of the five areas on the board. Numbered cards represent progress into a certain area. Typical with Reiner Knizia, there’s a little calculation and complication involved in the end scoring. A great 2 player game that can be expanded to 4 with 2 sets.

RATING: 3
There are a number of other card games for 2 players that I would recommend much more than this one. Extremely simple with luck of the draw being the biggest factor in the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating changed on 12/27/17, from 7.2 to 9.0

This is a game which I've given out multiple times as a wedding gift to gaming couples (or aspiring gaming couples) - but one which I thoroughly enjoy myself. Competing archaeologists, a la Indiana Jones, racing to collect the most points for each of 4 colors/dig sites. Forcing each player to decide what to hold and what to play, because cards must be played in ascending order.

But the game activates the gambler gene in all of us, because the card's numbers are its point value... AND it costs 20 points to start a dig... AND one can drop between 0-3 multiplier cards (for x2 points each) prior to any points... so a game can be anywhere from -40 points up to 90-some points. A gamble too far is still in good faith, right....?

(Written on 12/27/17)

RATING: 6
After many plays, I think this one's lost its luster. It's just uninspiring. Sure it's a strategic card game, but now our games of it lack any essential tension of struggle - it's as if we know the game too well, and so our actions come tacitly, without real thought, and luck rather than skill becomes the determinant factor. Thus, when the wife suggests a game of it, I won't say no, but inwardly the gaming experience just feels "meh."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A very enjoyable game, but my early impressions were that this game just has too much luck in it for my tastes. This feeling seems to be confirmed after viewing the results of thousands of games, courtesy of www.flexgames.com which includes an awesome online free version of the game. At flexgames, a chess-like ratings system is used, and the lack of a proper spread in the ratings, as can be found in the chess ratings, emphasizes how big a role luck plays in the game. Although, note that luck seems to be the key determinant only after you've developed the ability to avoid major errors in play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Old collection

My favorite short 2-player game from one of our favorite game designers: Reiner Knizia. Easy rules, short playing time and although it has a big luck factor, as most card games do, it requires a lot of tactical decisions to be made because starting an expedition costs 20 minus points. Are you going to wait one more round or are you going to put your card in the middle, maybe helping your opponent, or are you going to start to explore anyway, knowing that you're next card drawn will be the card you needed but cannot play anymore now... so easy but so frustrating! A cool card game that we always take on holidays with us!

We also own Keltis, based on the same principle, but that is less forcing you to play your cards as Lost Cities does.

RATING: 8.7
For a simplistic quick two player this game has a very deep strategy that you can invest in and it will pay you back. Sure you can gloss over and say it's a game where you are just waiting for cards but if you do, you'll never win against someone who is putting thought into their strategy. Lastly, you are on a clock to execute your strategy because there's only so many cards in the deck. Plan all you want but you better be able to lay down all those juicy 9s and 10s that you're holding onto!
Sleeved.

Lost Cities is a fun light two-player game.  Because it is a short game and not too complicated it is one game I can usually get my wife to play.  I think this is fairly universal and makes Lost Cities a favorite among significant others.  My only complaints are the games cost and the oversized cards.  There is no reason that this game couldn%u2019t have used a standard size cards and been sold for $10.  However, since it does get played quite often it is probably worth the price.

RATING: 7

Whilst the contest is good I don't feel there is enough player interaction. Players will often need to take chances on a colour based on the cards they hold. 

I liked it when I first found it but after 20+ plays I started to wonder and have now found much better card games that are more engaging like Battleline and other games in the Kosmos series.

Nice artwork.

RATING: 8
I like LC. It is simple and interesting and is very easy to teach and learn which I'm sure is why it has garnered the reputation of being one of the best Euro gateway games. It's not a particularly deep game yet there is still enough to think about that it doesn't all come down to luck and the better player will usually win...the sign of a game that isn't totally luck dominated. Replayability is good as the length of the game isn't severe and encourages rematches. I'd class this game as a great game to own for those wanting light filler style games and games which take very little set up and break down time. A good travel game as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost Cities is a Knizian 2 player card game quite similar to Battle Line. Play cards of different colors with values between 2 and 10 to different tracks, always of higher values and with the option to double the bet that the total value will exceed 20. An extra dimension is the discard pile, where cards discarded by you may be taken by your opponent. I still prefer Battle Line's tense fight for flags but I understand Lost Cities' appeal to many 2 player gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the fast pace of play.  I enjoy the 'Damn!' moments where you play your red 6 on your red 3, only to draw the red 5.  Sure, it's luck, but there's a degree of strategy.  I see definite trends over dozens of plays based on aggressive (me) versus conservative (my girlfriend) styles.  I'm more likely to end with a negative score one or more colors, but because I tend to pursue as many as 4 colors, I often end up winning anyway.  I see giving up cards and giving points to your opponent as often worse than using them yourself and potentially losing points on a color.

I tend to play this in 3 hand sets, with the points total of the 3 hands determining the winner.  This evens out some luck fluctuations, and adds new strategic elements.  For example, if you're 30 points down leading into the 3rd hand, you have a strong incentive to play aggressively to try to make up the difference, while your opponent may tend to play more conservatively to get just enough points to stay on top.

RATING: 5
The funny thing about Lost Cities is that I played it incorrectly for so long.  We never knew that you could pick up the cards that have been discarded, which is obviously a big oversight.  Since we've been playing correctly, I definitely like the game more.  It has some tough decisions, and the games always seem close.

I have grown tired of Lost Cities, though.  The game is very simple, and even though it doesn't take long to play, I find myself getting bored by the end of the 3rd round.  This is likely from having played a lot, but it nonetheless means I don't play as often, and that I don't rate the game as highly.  A good, light game, but there are other light two player experiences that I prefer.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
A very nice 2 player game.  Not too taxing or decision-heavy, and generally well-received by non-gamers, spouses, and the like.  A good introduction to German games (or Euro games, as some call them).  A little too luck-heavy to get a higher rating, but a nice way to spend some time with a buddy, especially while deciding what other game to play.  Also a very nice non-confrontational game for playing with the spouse.
