12-10-07: Lost Cities has stood the test of time and is still a great game to play after all these years. I'm less rabid about some of my other (newer) games and still love to play Lost Cities (maybe more than ever). Therefore, it moves from an 8 to a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The theme doesn't matter one bit in this game (although the sequential artwork is beautiful). What makes this game fun is the card allocation and scoring. You really have to monitor what your opponent is doing and make selective choices about which card sequences to go for and which cards to discard. The possibility of scoring negative points in this game is a brilliant way to force players to think strategically about their card choices. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
This is a very nice, quick, two player game that works well as a filler.  You could almost play this with a standard deck of cards, but you would need a fifth suit and some additional aces.  I like that there is suspense that builds to the end of the game.  The competition between the players is subtle, but well done.  I really enjoy this one.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost Cities is a great little 2-player game, up until the math at the end. Nevertheless, a game can be rattled off in 10-12 minutes. Tension really ramps up as the deck dwindles while players race to get their expeditions into the black.

The game itself is a kind of 2-player rummy/solitaire variant with a pasted on archaeology theme. My girlfriend likes it enough to request games and I could see my parents liking it too.

I'm not a fan of Lost Cities' artwork. The pencil crayon style looks unfinished.

As with all fillers don't play too many consecutive games in a row, 3 is probably the sweet spot.

This game reminds me a bit of a rummy, where you are trying to score more points than your opponent.  Quick, fun, and easy to teach.

RATING: 8
This game is simple, fast, and fun. Very good downtime game, especially when you don't want a game that is gonna make you think too much. The game is best if you don't agonize over your moves, because the cards will present you with many choices that you find unpalatable. There is a huge luck factor present, but there are also not a lot of deep strategies to get into so it's not often a frustrating game. It's very much what a light game should be.

RATING: 4.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Lost Cities[/b] was sold via auction 1/1/15 and again on 7/7/17.
Received in a math trade (8/8/14). 

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]I can appreciate the importance of Lost Cities when looking at all the card games that have been influenced by it's design. However I would much rather play Knizia's Battle Line, which I think is brilliant in its execution. 

If I am looking for a game that is in the same lineage as Lost Cities I'd choose Musée. Musee offers everything Lost Cities minus the wonky scoring and introduces a spacial aspect to the card play which adds more depth to the game but not complexity.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]- A great cafe game, small footprint (you don't need the board if you don't have room).
- Very easy to play/teach, but Mr. Knizia found a way to make it engaging.
- I like being able to change the tempo of the game based on whether you deplete the deck of cards or take a card from one of the piles of face up cards.
- The push your luck element: do you try to wait for one more handshake or do you start that third or even fourth expedition?
- While the scoring system seems wonky at first it makes the game. 

I prefer Knizia's Battle Line over this, but both will stay in my collection.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good 2 player game with wife

RATING: 10
Among the greatest two-player game.  Although you are in direct competition, it is not an 'aggressive' playing game.  With a shared set of resources you are each attempting to gain the best final result.
Since it is played in several rounds (three is standard but I like to play five.  It seems better balanced) you accumulate a final score in successive plays.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
Scandanavian Edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have only played this game a couple of times, but am eager to play it again.  The artwork is outstanding and charmingly evokes the turn-of-the-last-century archeology scene.  It's an easy game to learn how to play, and one that I was able to enjoy from the very start, without the usual "beginner's anxiety."

Update: I think now that I have played the game a few times and understand it better, it actually causes me more anxiety!  I still enjoy it, though, and look forward to the day when I will figure out a strategy for success. (5+5)   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I can see why this is popular with couples: it's a card game, the rules are easy to learn, play is quick and relatively short, there are choices to be made but not too many, and there are enough choices to make the game interesting. The game doesn't lend itself to being terribly competitive either, and because it's easy to learn, non-gamers might give this a look. As others note, it's very addictive. Once people get the hang of it, the game plays fast. Playing 3 games for a complete set is a good idea. I've played it with my sister and wife, who both like it. Maybe the coolest thing about this game is the artwork, namely, that if you lay out the cards in each color you'll notice that each successive card extends the story of an expedition...amazing. People who aren't very competitive may be somewhat put off by this, however. Purchased my copy in Boulder, Colo., while on vacation.

RATING: 7
I broke down and bought this today for full price at a FLGS that I was unaware of before last week--Blackfyre Games, nice place.  My wife and I have both been in a gaming mood lately, but without much time to get together with my brother and sister-in-law whom we usually game with.  We don't have a lot of good two player games, so we've been playing a lot of Blokus.  We love it, but we needed some variety.  I received Knizia's Spy for Christmas which was a major disappointment.  Started exploring this site and BSW around the same time and tried Lost Cities.  THIS is what we needed for the two of us.  So we splurged and got it tonight and played our first game of three.  We both had a lot of fun with an easy, but deep game.  Games that my wife and I enjoy playing frequently get high scores with me.

Magyar (Hosaka fordítása)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Like everybody else has pointed out, this is a good partner game but just a tad too light for me. By now I am mostly on autopilot while playing this because after repeated plays it becomes increasingly obvious what the optimal play is every turn.

There is a good amount of luck in this game so oftentimes, no matter how well you play, your opponent just gets the numbers when he needs them and you can't do anything but lose. That's probably the reason it's such a good partner game because even if your SO isn't really into games, they can still win against you without you having to hold back.

Shuffling the cards between and before the game is annoying though because sufficient shuffling takes up 25% of the time you commit to this game. And you have to shuffle sufficiently because If you don't, the colors will be clumped together from the previous game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
100+ plays. It's one of the great 2 player spouse games. It's light enough to play fast but there inevitably comes a few agonising decisions over how long to hold out for better cards (vs giving useful cards to your opponent via the discard pile vs playing too early to a colour and limiting your score in it). The other hard decision each hand is whether to play safe or risky (by playing multiplier cards on a suit that you may score negative in if you don't get the high cards). There's no direct pussage and limited interaction, but your plays generate enough interest and tension (from time pressure to maximise your score before the deck runs out) to warrant a lot of replay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not a bad little game, but usually 3 or 4 hands is enough for me.  A bit too dry to play for a long time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is probably my favorite 2-player Knizia card game. This is also one of my favorite 2-player Kosmos game.

Simple to learn.  Addicting.  Fast Play.  Scoring system is a slight hurdle, but makes sense, and gets easier to do the more you play and understand it.  Colorful.  Even non-gamers like this.  Fun and challenging, but simple design.  A perfect 2 player card game. Yes, the theme is pasted on, but I feel the graphic design makes it more pleasant and adds to the games' timelessness.

Some lesser mortals find this a little too mathy for their liking.

RATING: N/A
R
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Extremely easy to explain. 

I even like the pasted-on theme.

I like the artwork and the gameplay. Nothing mindblowing, but simple and enjoyable games are not easy to design. 

Players have to think before they make a move, but they get the feeling of Nice and Easy. 

Scoring is a pain in the ***. I made an Excel for it, but maybe I should delete it so I can get better at math.

(Wife's Point of View: I was pleasantly surprised. She asks for it all the time. The same girl that doesn't play Carcassonne because she doesn't like to think that much. She liked Jaipur, now she prefers this one. Everybody refered to it as wife friendly but I wasn't expecting much. I was wrong. It feels really easy going and fast despite it's mathy mechanics)

RATING: 8

Solid and fast; it'd probably only be a 7 if it took more than 10 minutes per game, but when it comes to quick filler it's hard to do better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I enjoyed this one immediately. Question though: How often will it get to the table? When looking for two-player, am I more like to play an abstract? (Twixt? Gipf series? Abolone?) There are a lot of other good 2-player card games out there (San Juan? San Marco? Rook? Canasta?). The "Indy-Jones" theme is a clever way to sell a relatively simple 5-suited game. I do like it, and it will be a good one to hook people into playing who might not be up for a traditional Euro, but don't (think) they feel like cards.

12/11/05 - after 20  games on BSW, the random element has started to annoy me a bit. Still a good title, probably too pricey for what it is. A good gift at $10. Not sorry I bought it, but dropped rating to 6.

2013: played over 100 games on iOS. Games last less than 7-8 minutes against AI, 10-12 minutes against a human. Perfect time, and addictive at this play speed. Raising to 7. Deleted game to save space in iPod. Huge time sink also!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For as often as my wife kicks my butt at this game, it's amazing I still enjoy it as much as I do!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My wife and I enjoy this game very much.  To me, few games have such agonizing decisions to make throughout the entire game.  Which expeditions should I try for?  Do I discard this card hoping my wife doesn't need it and draw from the deck?  Do I abandon an expedition at a loss and try another? Each game is very different. Great game!

RATING: 7
This is a small game that fits in my mind alongside Jaipur in terms of a great 2 player game that is quick and easy, but really forces you to make interesting decisions.  The game absolutely is NOT balanced every time.  We've ended a round where my wife scored nearly 100 points, and I had negative.  Sometimes, the cards you're dealt continually just are terrible, but the "best score after 3 rounds" makes up for it.  I actually won that game. So if you want perfectly balanced, look elsewhere, but if you want a fun game that is interactive, comically stressful, and rewarding, this is a good one.  Quick head-to-head play is perfect for spouses.

RATING: 6
It's a card game with 5 suits instead of 4. Also, it has nothing to do with any "Lost Cities" -- that is just artwork on the cards you never look at and has no relevance to the game.  Fun and addictive, absolutely no theme, but a good fast fun cardgame, and head-to-head competitive and tense, maybe too tense for non-confrontational players.

RATING: 5
Very famous and well liked game. But it seems to me that this game is basically about withholding cards that your competitor needs until they commit to building in that set and then you dump the cards they need which screws them so their scoring potential is limited. I don't see the fun in that.

Battle Lines has a similar feel, but is much more fun because players have more decisions, more complex decisions, and more agency to adapt and change strategy in mid-stream to minimize the damage of bad card draws or the impact of a "take that" delivered by an opponent.

RATING: 8
Brilliance.  Easy, simple, elegant, and quick.  But features never-ending second guessing -- not just against your opponent, but also the deck.  It's hard to imagine anyone developing a card game better than the best traditional card games, but this is it.  Better than cribbage, and certainly better than rummy/gin games.  Cards need to be redesigned -- too big,too difficult to tell apart, and too related to a theme that is pointless (let abstracts be abstract!).

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It is a game with simple rules that has a surprising amount of depth for a filler game.  You are constantly put at a crossroads in the game as to what to throw away that my opponent might take, what to keep, and what to play.  The handshakes or exploration funding is what makes this game really interesting since it multiplies the point scored, gains or losses.  And a lot of tension is produced by this.  This really solid filler that is you can get non-gamers into pretty easy.  I haven't played the board game that takes 4 players, but this version has got me interested in seeing what it is like.  Each round plays surprisingly tight.  When I first read the rules, I didn't at all expect this.  I give this an 8.   My wife will play it and it is surprisingly good filler.  If I were rating it as filler, I would give it a 9 or 10.   You can find the game for $10 and quick and very good play.  When I am playing it, I am never thinking "I wish I brought this other filler instead."  

The only thing I don't like about the game is the scoring.   Knizia has said himself that he develops a game around a scoring systems.  The scoring he believes is what drives the dynamics of the game.  In this game, the scoring drives the tension on starting expeditions.  If you fail and expedition, you could lose points, a lot of points if you fail it badly.  If you fund an expedition, your point loses or gains are multiplied.  This drives the game.  It works.  The downside is that it is a headache to adding up your score without a sheet of paper.  I am an engineer so I am better than most but if I am playing this at the bar without pen and  paper to track my scoring, I will finish adding up the score from one color x my funding level and completely forget what I scored in the previous color I added up.  I don't know how you fix this other than have a pen and paper handy.    The adding to negative numbers and multiplying negative numbers hurts my head if I don't have scratch paper and have had a beer.  The scoring works though and drives the game.  It just isn't the easiest to add up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Easy and quick.  There are some tough decisions to make in the beginning of each round.  Which cards to hold back, which cards to lay down, and which cards to discard.

RATING: 4
I bought this game based only on reviews and regretted it. I really don't understand what the fuss is all about. The expedition theme feels completely artificial and slapped on there. It's just a counting game. Yes, there is strategy and tactics involved, but the decision making is very straightforward. In fact, the best choice to make is often so obvious it doesn't even feel like I am making a decision. Moreover, luck still plays a big role, and it's simply frustrating to try and block your opponents line, only to have him draw a 10 or 9 in the colour he needs. My wife and I played this game twice and put it back on the shelf. It hasn't moved since.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Ótimo jogo para 2.

RATING: 7.5
An inexpensive, fast-playing, and enjoyable game for 2 people.  It does suffer from being 'over produced', as a resourceful person can quite easily 'make' this game with 2 decks of cards.  That aside, the game is fun with the calculations at the end being the worst part about it.

When do I play this?:
Well, to be honest, not often.  This is a game that I got after hearing so many reviews, but it doesn't really work for me and doesn't really 'grab' me.  It's okay for travels though, and is accessible to new gamers, so it's got it's plusses.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
*Have played this alot and been impressed that sometimes I come across a subtle tactical decision I haven't experienced before. I like the progressive images in each of the expedition cards, and game play has that advancing storyline, though doesn't have the exploration narrative of Africa. Has the Knizia trademark "Play a card, draw a card" which enforces speculative angst (though this is to a lesser degree then some of his other card games as you can draw from one of upto 5 discards). What increases the pressure is trying to get over the positive scoring threshold. The drawpile acts as a countdown to game end, the pace of which can be manipulated which I like. Quick pace is another good feature as sometimes plays are obvious. Can't intefere with opponent's play (so safe to play with your partner), all you can do is deny your opponent a valuable card to advance,though holding on to too many of those doesn't benefit you; so dilemmas creep in. On the whole Lost Cities quietly provides moments of consideration, quick to play but lacks the sharing of sitcom. Where it fails to do anything more for me is when I'm feeling competitive and need the thrill of comparing race situation:this requires maths gymnastics to discern current player status in order to make the best decision(though I guess the uncertainty maintains hope). Adding to this is the scoring which personally is an overlong, dull chore leading to an anticlimatic game session. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Simplistic, but quick and fun for 2 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
-

A fun and rather fast 2-player card game. It is easy and quick to learn with simple mechanics, yet allows for tactical and some strategical plays. Furthermore, there are elements of tension and risk taking, plus the variability of every hand, which give the game a tremendous amount of replayability value.  However, if both players are experienced in the game and have a good grasp of the various play tactics, winning boils down to literally 100% luck of the draw.

As far as the game's production, simply by using oversized cards, the publisher succeeds in enhancing the look and feel of the game and adding uniqueness to it, distancing it from being just another card game. Although, some purists may argue against trivially overdone components when a standard format could do just as well and might even be more functional.

For a similar game but somewhat more involved and more tense check out Battle Line. Another decent game in this vein is Odin't Ravens.

[Rating after dozens of play. First play on 03/16/05.]
[Update 06/28/07:  Rating increase from 6 to 7]

RATING: 9
Yes, in accordance with the cliché, my wife loves it.
And so do I. We can play 10 games in a row. I once used to play online almost everyday. It's so addictive.
Some say the theme is weak and pasted on, but I like the artwork and think it adds a lot to the game (I can't imagine playing it without the board and with standard cards, it wouldn't be the same).
The gameplay is pretty simple but also very clever. The strategy behind it is huge. A mediocre player can win a round to a good player due to their luck, but on the long run the best one always wins.
Simply the best choice for a quick but meaty two-player game.

RATING: N/A
One of the earliest card games I owned, and something that has earned a permanent place on my shelf. Really clever "play cards on opposite sides of a central board" 2p game, and allows for just enough tempo control to be interesting. As with many of these kinds of games, explaining scoring is a little tricky at first (you basically have a 20-point debt to repay for each expedition before you start tallying positive points) but it quickly becomes second-nature and the game can survive if you leave it on the shelf for a long time and pick it back up later.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A simple to grasp, fast playing game for two. 
Each person tries to build expeditions from the same pool of cards. The players have to add increasingly higher numbered card to their rows in order to make that row/expedition profitable by scoring as much points as possible. 
There is no direct confrontation in this game, just passive agressively hogging or (re-)taking cards your opponent could use and speeding up getting to the end by taking cards from the drawing deck. Easy to learn and fun to play. It might as well be themeless, but it has a sound system. An easy recommendation for anyone who plays games with their partner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
Played in Sept of 07.  It is a VERY solid game.  Nice balance.  A good variation on all card games.  Very quick to play.  I mean there is little one can complain about this.  Right?  Well, it is not my cup of tea.  There is little confrontation.  I believe Hera and Zeus is the best out of the Kosmos 2-player series.  This game just is not as exciting.  Again, though, very solid

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is an enjoyable two player card game.  You play three rounds scoring at the end of each round.  The round ends when the last card is taken from the draw pile (Not the five discard piles).  A turn consists of two actions; Your first action is to either lay a card or discard a card.  Your second action is to take a card from either the discard pile or the draw pile.  The moment you play a card you start with a negative 20 points.  Your optimum play would be to play two cards with hands first and then the matching color number cards in sequential order 2 through 10.  The hand cards are multiplier cards.  This can be good and bad.  If all you have down is a hand card when the draw pile runs out you will be a -40 points (-20 for starting the row times 2 for the hand card = -40 points).  If you have the following cards layed down you would have 18 points: (1)hand, 2, 4, 5, 8 and 10 (add up the value of the numbered cards, minus 20, times 2 = 18).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Quick thoughts: So far this game has proven to be a dud. Maybe there is something that I am not doing right. A sense of adventure is simply missing, and this is just a game where you place cards in ascending order. There is no sense of huge risk in this game, and as with most games and kids, the maths are a bit boring and complex. Instead of having a simple scoring mechanism, it is a bit stupid. Each expedition costs 20 points to start, and so you are trying to get 20+ points in the game. This is done simply by ignoring the lower value cards and focusing on the higher ones. Then there are the wagers or agreements which I am still uncertain about. Something about points doubling or something? I don't know. Example I realise that it is a multiplier. One agreement is 2x, two is 3x, and three is 4x. Does this mean that you need 40 points,60 points, and 80 points respectively, just to break even? I think that this game does have potential with a better explanation of the rules.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 6.5
This game is NOT "the perfect couples game" as some say - it's just a numbers-in-sets collecting game with a wagering multiplier - kinda like a cross between Gin Rummy and Spades. Theme nonexistent except for art on cards. It's nice, as a small cardgame, but there are many other games that are more unique and entertaining experiences.
That said, it is a good 2 player game for couples (in a relationship, or just a gaming partner) and could go up to as much as an 8 when played between 2 serious gaming partners. 
$.99 @ GW.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
When I first read the rules to Lost Cities I thought that it was a simple game.  After the first hand I played, I changed my mind.  The discard piles makes discarding tormenting, but you don't want to wait too long to start playing your sets or you won't have enough time to complete them.  This adds a complexity to the decision making that is hard to see from merely reading the rules.  I can understand how this game would be addictive because it makes me want to play again--hoping I will get cards in the right order, hoping I can extend the suspense.

There is a great deal of luck involved, but someone who has played the game more will invariably do better than someone who has played the game less.  One reason for this may be that veteran players have a better understanding of when they should and should not risk starting new colors or playing higher numbered cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4.5
I'm starting to think I'm not a huge fan of Knizia ;).  Lost Cities is an ok game, but I don't quite get what all the fuss is about it.  I had seen people talking this one up and to me it seems just... alright.

Update 11/9/09 :  I keep hearing there is great strategy in this game and I just don't see it.  Often there just seems to be one optimal play - and sometimes you just are presented with the choice of "a bad move" and "an even worse move".  If you are fortunate enough to draw the right cards then you just lay them down in sequence... no great decision making there.  I figure I'm missing something here or just suck at the game.  I don't hate it, and will play it if someone asks to, but it seems really average and vanilla to me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2 player easy to learn filler. Simple yet very entertaining.  You can play five games in 30 minutes. Simple rules, requiring players to draw then play cards of 4 different sets ("expeditions") in ascending order. Expeditions that are left significantly incomplete result in negative points, while those with many cards played (particularly high numbers) give a player points. This could be played with a standard deck of cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost Cities is in effect a card game - nothing more, nothing less. I happen to enjoy card games because my formative years where spent playing the usual family crap e.g. Game of Life, Monopoly, Trivial Pursuit, et al. I also played card games. 

In Lost Cities, you and your opponent play cards numbered 2-10 in 5 coloured sets to either the appropriately coloured set, or to the discard pile, with the objective of scoring the highest points. The key feature of the game is that when you lay a card to one of the appropriate coloured sets, you start from a position of minus 20 (-20) points after playing the first card to a coloured set. The numbers on the card represent the number of points when played on a set. 

You can also play cards that will double, triple or quadruple the value of any cards played to a set. These cards will, of course, also multiply any negative score.

From your own hand, and the cards that your opponent plays (and discards, as well as picks up from the discard pile), you have to deduce whether you can play to a set and overcome the negative modifier, and gauge how strong or weak your opponent is in a particular colour.

The cards are of good quality, and the back of each coloured set of cards make a nice tableau.

My fiancee and I played a lot of games when I first bought Lost Cities a couple of years ago over Christmas, and then never went back to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Mathy but delicious, Lost Cities is a game that anybody who has a background in regular card games will love. Simple and easy to learn as rummy, but with enough subtle strategy to keep it running, LC is a game of tense decisions and the temptation of taking risks. Do you play an investment card when you are unsure that you'll be able to complete a viable expedition in that particular color? The questions are endless, the hands seem to end too quickly. Great game, one that you can pull out with literally anyone and have a good time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Simple yet very entertaining 2-player filler. You can play five games in 30 minutes. Simple rules, requiring players to draw then play cards of 4 different sets ("expeditions") in ascending order. Expeditions that are left significantly incomplete result in negative points, while those with many cards played (particularly high numbers) give a player points. This could be played with a standard deck of cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players: 2
Time: 45 min. (3 rounds)

Card game in which players mount "expeditions" by collecting same-colored cards which are numbered 2-10. The first twist is that you cannot play a lower numbered card than the highest number you currently have for an expedition (i.e. cards must be played from low to high). Your score for that expedition is the sum of the numbers minus 20. So the second twist is that if the sum of your numbers in an expedition is less than 20, you will get a negative score. You can also play investment cards prior to embarking which multiply the profit (or loss) of any expedition. Sarah's favorite 2-player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.39
A simple set building game from Knizia. The central mechanic is easy to pick up (lay down cards from lowest to highest, rather like a game of patience) but the catch is that you and your opponent are working from the same set of cards and there is a penalty for making a half-hearted attempt at any particular set.
The game is fun but it gets a lower rating for being two player. The reason is fairly simple, if I was going to play two player I wouldn't pick something with this much luck, I'd want either something heavier or a perfect information game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Among the best games to come off Knizia's long production line of lightish card games, Lost Cities has both simple rules and a fair number of strategic points to learn - and is incredibly addictive when you first learn it (at least, it was for my wife and I back in 2011). Unfortunately, it doesn't sustain this initial surge of interest, as you gradually realise that there isn't much you can do if the cards you need for your high-scoring "expeditions" don't come your way. While perhaps it is our fault for overplaying it early on, I never have any interest in breaking Lost Cities out again these days - but I still have plenty of respect for the game. Although it's worth pointing out that Battle Line, another 2p Knizia card game, feels pretty similar in most respects - despite being mechanically quite different - while retaining interest far better over repeated plays.

RATING: 6
Another great two player filler. The struggle of deciding how many expeditions to go for, whether to play investment cards, when to play a significantly higher card than your previous one, and what to discard make for some good decision making. Can have a very high frustration level - drawing a card just less than the one you just played, for example - and that initially made me question whether or not I liked this game. But after s few more tries, that frustration turned into one of the more appealing aspects of the game.

RATING: 8
An astounding amount of tension and enjoyment for such a simple idea. Doesn't allow for that much creative play, but tense as hell. Neat.

Ratings upgraded after playing regularly for a year and not getting bored.

How the hell does Knizia make a game out of counting up? 
---
Ratings upgraded again after more years of contemplation. I've been underrating this game, I think, still. It's not aiming for my favorite target - it's virtues are its learnability, its ease of play, it's relatively narrow decisions pace. It's not a monster-soul of a killer of a game - but the design is so clean and play is so surprisingly engaging. Also, I've played it like 200 times, and that's gotta count for something.

It's still the first game I recommend for a new-to-gaming couple that wants something gentle, but a real game.

RATING: 10
pure genius - takes a fairly enjoyable card games, gives it 2 key twists (multiple shared discard piles and a player controlled end of game) and somehow contrives so you never actually WANT to play ANY of your cards :) i love it

oh and btw if anyone gives this less than 10 they are wrong

PLAY THIS INSTEAD OF - Balloon Cup, Schotten Totten.

IF YOU LIKE THIS TRY - 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lot's of interesting decisions with this one.  You'll want to horde cards you know your opponent needs, but that means you probably have to sacrifice something with your own sets.  The deck is pretty short, so there's tension in knowing your time is limited to create the ultimate sets.  Do you wait to start an expedition hoping you draw better cards and discard something that might be what your opponents needs, or start an expedition in a worse position than you would hope for?  Agonizing at times, but still pretty fun.  Great game.

RATING: 9

We have played Pandemic and Carcossonne and a few others and understood the strategies to win but this game is so simple and the mechanics seem light but quickly surprise you with their depth. It has been a really enjoyable experience for us to play this and I highly recommend it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
04-10-2014. Rated after a couple of 4 more plays.
In this game you'll score many points in a certain color. Each color (5 colors) features cards from 1 to 10. Each card occurs just once and if you play a number, you cannot play lower numbers. Complication also, is that there are multiplier cards which cause you to win (or lose in case..) multiplied amount of points. You try to estimate the likelihood of occuring the amount of high cards in the deck. Problem, you don't know what your opponent has and what's left in the deck. You need at least 20 points in 1 color to come out positively. 

13-10-2013. Rated after a couple  plays.
I suck in this game, but the GF likes it.

RATING: 4
----------

There isn't much to this game... you have a few decisions to make, but none of them seem to carry much weight since the game goes by so quickly.  It doesn't matter too much if you mess up because a new round is only 5 minutes away.  This leads to 90% of the game being played on autopilot.

I'll play if I'm bored... wait, why did I say this?  I'll probably never play this game again.  (And I won't care one bit).

I own kilgore's retheme version (thanks TGov!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I feel like I owe Lost Cities an apology. I spent a lot of years actively hating it, assuming that most people we're crazy for thinking it was anything besides a goofy crapshoot of a game. I thought it was impossible to gauge risk and that victory hinged entirely on what cards you draw, not on how you actually plan.

But I sensed I was out of step with the general consensus, so I spent some time reading about strategies and how to play well. I'm ashamed to say that a lot of what I read never occurred to me, obvious though they might be in hindsight. After giving those some thought and playing a couple games with my wife, I found that though Lost Cities is a very simple game, it's definitely not stupid and random. It's a game filled with tense decisions and just a hint of thematic flavor that makes more sense the longer I think about it.

So now I've done a complete 180 on Knizia's classic. Right now it's one of my favorite two-player games, and definitely one of my favorite games to play with my wife.

RATING: 6
A very simple game idea that leads to plenty of choices. It's really a game about pacing and compromise, and making the best use of what you have. The bits are of excellent quality (tarot sized cards etc).

The downsides are some unexpectedly agonising AP and the luck of the draw, though given that it's a lighter game neither are particularly troubling.

There's been something of a backlash against this game on BGG lately, but playing it again recently made me appreciate it anew. A good light game, and a great gateway game.

Update: losing interest in this lately, as the scoring is a bit fiddly for such a light game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a mathematics/numbers game.  There are 5 expeditions, each with 3 investment cards and 1 copy of each number between (and including) 2 and 10.  Each turn you play a card either into one of your expeditions or onto the discard pile for that expedition.  Then you draw a card, either from the draw pile or from one of the discard piles.  When you play a card on your expedition the card you play must be of greater value than the one previously played.  At the end of the game, as soon as the draw pile is empty, each player totals their expeditions, subtracting 20 points from each expedition they contributed to.

The tension in the game comes from deciding when to start an expedition and which ones to abandon, as trying to play all of them will result in negative points for at least one.  Players are making decisions based on the totals they can make, as well as deciding to give up a card their opponent might take in order to stall and hope for a better draw.

It plays fast, but is rather light on strategy.  It makes for a great filler or casual game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I don't know why this game is so addictive, but it really is!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Having heard many things for this "classic" game, I thought of finding more about it and was able to test it online. I found out why were there so many controversial comments here. So after 20-30 games that's what I saw;
Why many people love it?

-It is so simple to learn.
-It is very fast and lasts no more than 5-10 min.
-It is different each time you play it.
-It has some(many) difficult decisions.
-It is one of those rare board game that is so easy to get your wife to play with, and love it!
-Its theme fits very well and it's something different. They even avoided having goblins (or zombies...) making the excavations!

Why people hate it?
-It is soooooo simple even for a filler...
-It is soooooo much luck based. It would be ok to have luck involved but from what I saw, a player may have lost the game as soon as the shuffling ends.
-Pointless decisions. Yes you just made a difficult decision, but what you realise after a while is that when the outcome of the decision is so much based on luck you could as well just pick a card and skip the thinking. It's something you easily realise when someone asks you to pick a number for a dice roll, and you just call a whatever number. The difference here is that there are minor differences on the choises and you are tricked to think that it matters. If you think is worth to squeeze your brain to find which option has 54% of success and which 46% then go ahead, be a master on this game.
-It is easy to get your wife to play with it, exactly because it seems to have some depth, but she will win half the game anyway because it's just a luck game. And she will be the cool wife that plays board games with her husband!!!
-If the theme was investing on summoning zombies, goblins, vampires and dragons to make the most fearful army it would probably be more "cool". Yes really it could have any theme. Why bother buying a game that you could easily play with one and a quarter decks of playing cards. On the other hand, there are people that go and buy Rummi...

As for me the only chance I see playing this one again is by making a PnP copy myself with a different theme to play with my wife and kids when they grow a little. Or have them play and I play Diablo. Or if everyone is willing to play we better play hearts.

This was surely a very good and innovative game back there at 1999 when people were obsessed with Windows Minesweeper. But as Roland of Gilead can asure you, the world has moved on. And better so should you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Sort of silly - lots of luck, threadbare theme, but kind of fun in a pointless way. It's all a gamble and I enjoy the multiplayer Keltis card game easily over this.

RATING: 7
Another tense card game for two players, this time from Dr. Reiner Knizia.  There are 5 cities in a different color, each with 10 cards and 3 multipliers.  You are trying to get the most points you can by building expeditions based on playing cards from lowest to highest.  If you don't score high enough, you lose points!  Tough decisions must be made throughout, and tensions can get pretty high!

RATING: 8
Really great, well-balanced, two-player card game. A true classic. The only quibble I have is that, like with most Knizia games, it's the manipulation of cold probabilities -- the theme is interesting and evocative. And completely unnecessary. It's really just bunch of math, ho hum.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Not a big fan anymore, and here's why: after playing a few times, you figure out all the strategy, play to the best of your capability, and the rest is luck. Each turn, you either have a very, very obvious action to take, or you don't. If you do, you take it, and it's scripted. If you don't, you take a risk on doing something, and the thing you end up doing is always a crapshoot which you hope will turn out good for you. Each turn, you either follow the right thing, or you close your eyes and pick something almost completely random to do. Not a good decision. Will still play as a filler, or to trash people who think this is a deep game. Need a scoring track for this.

3+1

RATING: 8
This is one of my favorite 2-player card games--if only I could get my wife to play more often.  I've seen a lot about this being a Rummy knock-off.  However, there is no melding, which seems as though it should be a prerequisite for a game to be termed rummy-like.  Despite being superfluous, I really like the artwork as well.  As far as gameplay, there is some luck, as with most card games.  However, like any good card game, it rewards skillful play.  I've also noticed when I've playe with different people that styles of play have occurred that I was not familiar with or did not expect to work.  Hopefully, it will continue to entertain.

RATING: 7
I like playing this game turbo, and finishing within 10 minutes or less. New players will probably fumble around the first game, with its slightly strange scoring system. The key to this game is not to overthink your difficult decisions - just think fast and take your actions now! 

OK, so this game has a pasted-on theme, and is a little mathy. But if you can complete it in 15 minutes, you'll probably agree to another round of it.

RATING: 8
A simple to grasp, 2-player card game with mechanics that cause anguish in the decision making. A lot of hidden interaction that allows you to be semi-devious without your opponent ever feeling like you've screwed him over. Of course, by doing so you may be hindering your own development, so there are two sides to every coin in this game. Great fun. Coins not included.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[57 plays] Surprising amounts of thought and tension for such a simple little game. It plays like a feisty, competitive game of solitaire for 2. (That may make sense after you've tried it.) It is quick and is highly addictive.

My parents, who are in their mid-late 70's are now complete addicts of this game after I gave them a copy for Christmas 2004. They taught themselves the rules. Their running total is now 53,000 points to 49,000 points with Mom in the lead after almost 18 months of continuous play. (their stats updated 6-7-06 )

Most recent plays 11-6-06 with Dad at deercamp.

RATING: 7.5
A high rating because of its accessibility to newbies!

For a 'gamer' the game can get a little too static and dull. There are shades of rummy (play a card and draw a card from draw or discard pile) and the typical Kniza agony (do you build your hand slowly or take risks with expeditions).

The theme is pathetically thin (explorers my arse) but the artwork and oversized cards and even the board is a plus.

RATING: 7.5
This is one of the first games that my wife actually liked and still requests to play from time to time.  That's a great thing and I actually like the game as well.  She used to beat me all the time, but I've since improved.  Anyway, there is quite a bit of strategy packed into this simple card game.  I would describe it as elegant.  Yes, the scoring math can be a bit annoying, but it gets easier and easier with each play.  I personally think that the theme works with the game and offers a good way to explain the play while teaching it to others.  This has become a classic card game and will always be in my collection.

RATING: 7.75
A seemingly simple concept of set collection with a dose of press your luck. Deciding which cards to start a set, which ones to discard, or which to hold in your hand (to deny your opponent) make for a rather strategic card game. A really good 2 player card game with just a small amount of "good-natured screwage" to it, highly recommend for non-gamers and/or couples.

RATING: 7
Quick and fun game, OK once in a while or to finish off an evening but repeated play against the same player gets a little repetitive.  The agonising decisions of what to discard, what to play and when are what make this game good.  What I haven't quite worked out is how informed these decisions really are - can you really know whether you should hold onto your cards a few more turns or just play them?  Still it creates tension and I still have not tired of it.

RATING: 7.715
It can be an easy but frustrating game. I was thinking that a person could play a four-land version of Lost Cities with a simple deck of playing cards. The four aces could be used as board markers while the three face cards could be used as investment cards. (I guess someone could invent a version where the king's investment would be more valuable than the queen's which would be worth more than the jack's. Perhaps someone could try an option where the king is worth two investment cards, the queen is worth one investment card, and the jack is used as an eleven or some type of negative card to place on the opposing player.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[2011-08-13]
A Keltis kártyajáték után ismertem meg a nagy elődöt, így úgy tudnám röviden jellemezni, hogy a Keltis 2 játékosra optimalizált változata az Elveszett városok. A szabály 1 perc alatt ismertethető, maga a játék 10-15 perc maximum. A játékosok 5 színben 2-10-ig számozott kártyákból képeznek növekvő sorrendet egy-egy kártya lerakásával a körükben. Minden új szín megkezdése -20 pontról indul és a benne levő kártyák összege adja a végén a nyert pontot. Ez még meg van fejelve minden színből 3 szorzó lappal, amit ha az elején bevállal a játékos, akkor kapott eredményét az adott oszlopban megszorozza a lerakott szorzólapok számával. Szerencsejáték tulajdonképpen, de mivel pörgős, gyors így egymás utáni 3 parti azért csökkenti a mértékét. Szép a kivitel, de fölöslegesen nagyok lettek a kártyák és a tábla is nélkülözhető lenne. Simán játszható akár a Keltis kártya lapjaival is. Nem egy nagy játékról van szó, ami szinte teljesen mechanikus, nagyon ritkán kell dönteni benne, de abszolút játszható és a rövid játékideje miatt elővehető.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
well- classic thats really it...OK no its not :)

Cons: Probably the adding up at the end but otherwise theres no other con that isnt a pro due to its interated mechanics - such as the cards run out before you can finish your plans but thats why the game is so 'moreish'

Pros: good fun, fast and one of the best 2 player games around. My partner is pretty fussy with games but he always comes back for more of Lost Cities. This game, because its fast and easy to learn is one of those low investment games for people who whinge when you try to get them to play - just grab Lost Cities -tell them its easy as and quick and the game will make sure they play multiple rounds as its so addictive.

RATING: 8
Lost Cities is an enjoyable 2-player card game that offers quite a bit of tension and decision making for such a simple game. I've had a lot of success introducing it to new players, despite the complicated scoring system. The structure definitely helps with teaching as by the time you get into the third round, new players are more comfortable with the mechanisms. This usually leads them to remark "let's play again" right after final scoring. It has waned a bit for me over the years, but I still enjoy playing it from time to time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Sounded like a good idea and I usually love Knizia games, but when half the game time is spent on totalling the score, that's just too much boring math for my taste. Ultimately the game lost its appeal when I realized I could play it with any five suit deck. Taken this way, it is just a regular card game modified to use a fifth suite, and since there are five or six suit card decks available, a separate game of "Lost Cities" is simply redundant.

RATING: N/A
PNP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
LOST CITIES! This is a great game. It scratches the same itch as Battle Line but it is a game my wife will actually play. 

I love the risk of laying a new color. You are often forced to give your opponent points just so you don't have to lay on a color you know you can't get. The timing mechanic is also great. You need to wait until you get the right cards but if you wait too long, you will not get all of your cards laid.

You can have a round screwed over by unlucky draws. But over three rounds usually the person who plays better will win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
I have a soft spot in my heart for Lost Cities, because it was our gateway into designer games after my husband and I got married. I wanted to get us a two player game and was tired of playing Monopoly and Boggle, so I saw this had good reviews and bought it for us. We played it like crazy and then bought more games and eventually we're going to a Gaming Center and trying out games frequently and I'm part of a gaming group. 

I feel like I've sort of grown out of Lost Cities, but play it every once in a while for those moments when I feel like playing a quick and easy game that doesn't require too much thought. There is some strategy to it, but not enough variation and complexity to enjoy it on a regular basis.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fine way to pass the time with two players, Lost Cities' rules are simple enough that children who understand numerical ordering and multiplication can play.  The game is also nuanced enough to be enjoyable for adult gamers.

Risks and rewards depend solely upon which cards players keep, play, and discard.  This adds a moderate amount of tension to the game.  The beginning and middle part of the game rely heavily on inferring the opposing player's strategy.  Discarding cards is the closest thing to interaction between the two players in this game, as the discarded cards form a common draw pool.  As with most card games, the luck of the draw will come into play as well.

The game is a small card game and good for packing away for a trip.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A fun, quick game for two.  Fair amount of luck, but for a quick game, that's OK.  Enough thinking to keep me coming back.  Good game for non-gamers.  I have the Midgaard (non-english) version.

RATING: 2
[thing=50][/thing]

Picked it up after hearing good things about it, combined with the limited selection of games designed for two players.  At its best, its a coin toss who wins.  At its worst, you end up so far behind you'll never catch up. Even when the games were close, I didn't feel there was potential to affect the game outcome.  Combine that with a weak theme, and it seems like filler.  For the price you should buy a deck of cards and some gin, the fun will last longer that way.

Pros: Quick Setup

Cons: Weak theme, feels like playing tic tac toe

RATING: 7
Very fun, excellent quick-and-meaty 2 player game - a rare niche - which is its greatest strength and also its greatest weakness. Strong because no other 2-player game can achieve the amount of game it packs in the short amount of time, but also weak because the price point feels expensive for something that is only two players and lasts less than 10 minutes. Battle Line offers a more satisfying version but takes longer as well - about half an hour. Lost Cities (playing with someone knowing the rules) can take less than 10 minutes (or even 5 with very decisive opponents).

RATING: 6.75

I had pretty much all the 10s for all the cities in 2/3 rounds and still lost.  Although if the person I was playing with didn't get the +20 8 card bonus, I would have won maybe, or it might have been a tie.

Anyhoo, it's a game I'd play every now and then but not like something I'd play over and over and over...

RATING: 6
[many plays] This game is decent.  The strong point is that there is a lot of tough choices, what do you discard, when do you start a color vs wait.  But ultimately IMO there is not great replay value here.  The game is overloaded with trying to calculate the odds of getting something better vs playing what you have right now.  There is a fair amount of match in this game.  It is an okay game, I have played against my sister, my wife, people in my gaming group, people online, etc.  I don't "dislike" playing this game at all.  However, I just don't have any feeling of wanting to play or suggesting to play this game either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[RGG Scandinavian 1999 edition] {Adventure, couple; set collection, drafting, risk-taking} Lost Cities is a nice 2p game. It is very suitable for a couple who dislike confrontation games.  Players are competing in getting cards for scores. LC is a risk-taking game with clever scoring mechanism.  It is fast-paced, thematic and meaty.  Highly recommended as a couple game with 30 minutes.

It is quite interactive.  It does not offer direct interaction but the indirect competition is fairly strong, where players are competing for suitable cards and working to end a game for their best. In LC, you cannot ignore how your opponent plays in investing an exploration. If he is investing the same exploration, you know that your chance of getting high score is smaller. If your opponent is investing an exploration, you may hold cards to reduce his income. Therefore, I don't agree with my friends that it's a 2-p solitary game.

Card counting skill is important but not critical because it is usually too late if you discover what cards are remaining or your opponents are holding.  Intuition is important in LC.  If you have a good feeling what your opponent is working on, you can develop a good game plan to get good score.

[Sessions] I have experienced several games that my opponent got the 8, 9 and 10 in all 5 suits. Maybe, it's just my bad luck in card draws :(.

RATING: 5

Still, we had a good 2 years play out of this and I would heartily recommend to those who haven't played before. I've uaccrued literally 100s of plays both online and offline. I'd recommend this game without hesitation to people looking for a 2 player game. I do occasionally play online still.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There is a whole family of card games known "competitive patience" games; and Knizia's game mostly closely resembles one called "Spite and Malice" which you can look up on the pagat website. This game adds scoring including the use of the "bonus cards" or whatever they are called. So it's a nice game, clean rules, some interesting choices. Based on how I feel about playing it again, I'd rate it "7", but I have to knock of one ranking pt. for the lack of originality. 

The problem with two player card games is that it can boil down to card counting if the game plays with all the cards. This part is the most annoying, you inevitably get to a pt. in the game maybe halfway through and one or both players start to stall, until one of them realizes he may as well draw down the deck. It's not very satisfying strategically when this happens and it's starting to happen a lot now...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The orginal rules is not much fun. But try this:
play the game on 4 player in 2 teams. You are not allowed to communicate with your team mate about what to do. This is way more fun! You need to cooperate and play your high cards in the right time. Another thing that improves the game is to introduce a random card. Whenever you want to you can instead of playing a card draw one from the pile that you then must play. This can be good if you only got high cards for instance and want your teammate to play an important card first. But it is risky since it can ruin a lot if you draw the wrong card. These two improvements makes the game so much more fun! Try it, we have for almost 1000 games now. Yes really. ;-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The only game we have were we just want to play over and over!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
The 2 player classic!

It quickly faded in our home. 5 expeditions available to start, each gives you points, but they also have a start-up cost. You can increase the investment in any given expedition, thereby ensuring a bigger profit - or loss.

You play cards onto your own expeditions, each card can only be followed by a card of a higher value. The break-even point is 20 points, so a minimum of 3 cards is needed.

On your turn you MUST play a card either by starting/ continuing an expedition or by discarding it. Each type of expedition has its own discard pile and cards are played into it, covering any previous cards. It is sweet to discard a high card for an expedition you have forfeited, but your opponent is working at, once they have played the next higher card, thus making it impossible for them to play it.

You end your turn by drawing a new card, either from the draw deck or from the face-up discards. The game ends once all cards have been drawn from the deck.

Initially this was a big hit for us and saw repeated plays, however, it quickly wore out. The main reason for this was the lack of theme. No, we did not feel like we were working on exploring the Incas or any of the Pyramids (or whatever the expeditions were meant for). The game lacked strategic depth. Neither of us are comfortable with mathematics to the extent we can calculate the odds of such and such happening. Neither of us enjoyed the bluffing game, figuring out where to lead and where to follow and where to hold off.

Simply put, the lack of game in this title quickly showed.

I continually hear high praise for the game and have on occasion been back to read other peoples thoughts. There are claims for strategic depth, but I think of a kind that does not suit us (as attempted addressed above) nor does the quick play time entice us, we have better alternatives for that.

We took one shot with the game as a gateway game, it bombed. There has been nothing said that makes me regret selling it on.

That said, I can see where people come from but still I would not recommend the game. Why not dive straight into meatier stuff than this...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Many decisions to make, but easy to learn and simple to set up!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8

I love the almost 'push your luck' aspect, the interaction (what cards have my opponents played/what is still in play?), the single set of cards, the 'double or nothing' feature, the tension, the pacing, everything. 

It's a bit light, a bit luck based, a bit abstract. But it plays so well. Should I withhold cards that will help my opponent but are clogging up my hand? How many moves are left for me to achieve what I want to? Should I slow the game or rush to do what I need? Risk it and play a 5 on a 1? But what if I am about to draw a 2? All of these choices/questions and more, each turn, each game. I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very fast, extremely simple card game with a nice but superfluous board. It's very good quality, though, and the art is lovely. The theme is definitely tacked on, so it's difficult to get in the spirit of the quest as you might with "Battle Line," another quick card game with some similar features. The mathematics involved in scoring can be a bit of a turn off, although it's simple enough and the game provides a very good example of the system in the rules. Overall, really easy to learn and a decent filler between heavier/longer games or when you have a few minutes to spare. I rarely ever suggest it but it seems to be a big hit with hesitant gamers, which is always a plus.

RATING: 8
Great 2-player game. One of my favorites and one of the first Euro card games my husband and I got into. We joined a local gaming group and met Agricola (German version, not available in U.S. yet) and Space Alert (same story) at the first gathering we attended. Exploring the host's 2-player shelf we discovered Lost Cities and realized we already owned a copy. Tim had picked it up at a thrift store in San Diego years before. Needless to say Lost Citites got a lot of play after this. Our cards look pretty worn now. 

Love the Keltis spin-off, particularly the board game expansion: Keltis: New Paths, New Ways.

Reviewed on TheGlassMeeple.com

RATING: 8
An elegant, subtle game.  Another game that I really love for the way it handles risk.  Another Knizia game that really packs a lot into a small amount of time: tactically and strategically interesting, there is really a lot of information you can get and withold from your opponent, a lot of ways to psych them out and trick them (discarding cards to temp them to start things they shouldn't), a lot of tension will still being a calm, quick playing game.  Really, I don't know how he does it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I was in two minds about buying this game. Given you could make your own version using standard playing cards it didn't seem value for money. In the end I decided to pick it up as a filler to qualify for free postage on another order. I'm really glad I did - this game is just about perfect, it's simple, elegant, quick, and deep. It's also living proof that nice components and a pasted on theme add significant value to a game. I can't imaging enjoying this as much using a home made deck.

10 plays: Still enjoying the game although I'm beginning to suspect that the luck element is quite high (stays at 9).
20 plays: Luck element is definitely significant but still great fun (stays at 9). Can see my rating dropping a point or two over time however.
30 plays: Still going strong.
40 plays: I've had this game for just over a week and the cards are starting to wear out!
50 plays: My wife and daughter just can't stop playing this.
60 plays: Still having great fun playing.
70 plays: I have become reconciled to the luck element in the game. I am winning approximately two-thirds of games and now understand that the game is all about managing risk and making appropriate choices in the face of uncertainty. Sure, you may still get hosed by luck but over a large number of games the better player should still prevail. If I get to 100 games and am still enjoying it this much, I'll definitely give it my first 10 rating.
80 plays: My opinion hasn't changed.
90 plays: Still on track for a 10 rating as I'm still enjoying playing.
100 plays: My first 10! Any game that I can play 100 times in under two months and still look forward to playing deserves a 10 by the BGG definition.
150 plays: I still enjoy playing this game so it must remain a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Easy filler game. A little risk reward in going on expeditions and needing cards that go up in number in order to complete.

RATING: 6
I think I would like this better if Battleline or Balloon Cup had never existed.



Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 4
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 4
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 1
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 4


Overall - 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
2- Player, Ellen, Light
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Simple design / simple rules,  that somehow yields loads of fun with everyone I have tried it with.  Despite starting with a hand of 8 cards,  that claustrophobic feeling can sink in right from the start.

While not a deep game by any means,  this one is chock full of tough choices throughout.  Should you risk starting another expedition,  how long can you wait hoping to draw lower cards on a previously invested one,  how much can my hand withstand the clogging of my opponents cards,  will discarding this card cost me too much or should I just play it.........

Yet, despite all of the above,  I find this one of the most relaxing gaming experiences I have ever encountered.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Before we bought this, I was all excited for this game and the "expedition" theme that was so highly advertised.  As an archaeology Major, I honestly don't know what I was expecting - each box to come with a specially packaged artifact?!  The game is fun and can get pretty tense if you over-explore and get into some trouble, but I just didn't like the tacked on civilizations theme.

RATING: 7
Classic 2 player push your luck design that entirely hinges around the decision to commit to a color, or wait till you get better cards before committing.  Exquisitely designed, this makes that one simple choice an agonizing decision each and every turn (and you will ALWAYS draw that 7 right after you play your 8)!  I prefer Battle Line, but this is pretty damn good too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A really fun game for two players.

There are some strategy and tatics on it, tough luck plays it's part in a considerable way (as, if you go to find the Red City, and most of the reds cards end up in your adversary hand).

But, as with the best games that envolve luck, it is a fast game. The box says it last around 45 minutes, but usually takes around 30 minutes or less (if you take out the final scoring).

The game is fast, fits in a is small and is affordable. Really recommended!

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/723215/lost-cities-resenha-em-portugues-review-in-portu]here[/url].

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game scores points in my book as a wife game. While I'm not totally wild about it, my wife likes it and beats me regularly - which makes it enjoyable for both of us. There is very little to the game, just a deck of large cards with mediocre art. The mechanic is the key in this game. There is lots of decision-making within the confines of the very simple gameplay. The scoring takes a while because you have to do lots of adding and subtracting and multiplying. In my opinion, not as enjoyable as Jambo or Balloon Cup, but this is a good enough Knizia game, and is a good wife game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very "easy-going" game. There are some strategies, but overall not too much thinking. Easy and fast to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
the perfect 2 player filler game. look no further.

my own gaming tastes are changing enough that I find myself wanting to play the game less and less, though I still recognize it as a superior game, filled with the special addictive qualities that really make a game shine.

The biggest problem for me is that the decisions are either fairly easy when you have "the right cards" or impossibly difficult when you don't. In other words, there are times you have to make a tough decision but have no reason to choose 1 way over the other(s). This then becomes less about interesting tough decisions and more about getting lucky.

but that doesn't come up so often and the game is light and short enough to make it pretty easy to overlook.

RATING: 6
It's a good game, with nicely agonizing decisions. But you could play this with two decks of standard cards (5 suits needed). It's not a cost thing, I just maybe want a little more to a game design than something that could be written up in a couple of pages in a book of card games. Still, it fills a certain role pretty nicely--a ten or fifteen-minute game that's light but challenging from the first turn to the last, with some "let's-play-again" appeal.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lost Cities is a card game from the Kosmos two-player series. The object is to mount profitable expeditions to one or more of the five different lost cities. Card play is quite straightforward, with a few agonizing moments sprinkled through what is mostly a fast-moving game. If you start a given expedition, you'd better make some progress in it, or it'll score you negative points. If you can make a lot of progress, you'll score quite well. After three rounds, the highest total score takes the day.

RATING: 7
The most played game that I own.  Whenever my sons visit, they will start up a game since it is possible to play and remain sociable.  The game requires good intuition rather than card counting, and even the luck involved is enjoyable.  How often does one draw the needed card on the last turn when it can no longer be played?

But at this point, I prefer to play Babel, Roma, or Battle Line.

RATING: 7
Decent (if typically math-y and at-first-blush-counterintuitive) Knizia hand-management game, with elements of luck-pressing, deduction, and timing. RATING: 7
Great game, if you don't mind a bit of math at the end. 

The theme is fairly dry and doesn't come through during play. It is an abstract game about numbers, at heart.

But it is very good at what it does. You are forced to make challenging and interesting decisions and the play time is so quick that, if you are like me, rushing to the end and counting up your score is just plain fun.

Is a winner for a 2-player collection.

RATING: 7
During my first few plays, the game's simplicity made it feel like a no-brainer filler game. As players got more experienced, however, it got a lot more tactical. Now, it provides a good challenge that requires sound tactical decisions, bluffing and taking (calculated) risks. Recommended after all, and better that its spin-off boardgame counterparts (which have too many rules considering their simple premise). Perfect as a gateway (filler) game for your nongaming girlfriend.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I bought this game at DragonCon 04.  It breaks most of my rules for a good game.  It is practically a regular card game (just short one suit).  It is really an abstract game; I don't feel any connection to the theme at all.  Why do I like it?  For one, rules are for boardgames, not boardgame selection.  Mostly, though, it is fast, and while it feels light, the choices are significant.  Luck is significant, but not overwhelming.

P.S.  My interest has dropped a little over time.
P.P.S.  After a long break, my most recent game felt fresh again.  :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
The first game that my wife and I played together (thanks to the boardgamegeek community). What can I possibly say that has hasn't already been said? This game is an elegant, transportable, simple-yet-deep game that has a great strategy-to-luck ratio. Not as confrontational as Battle Line, which is the game that killed Lost Cities for us, and ultimately not as stimulating due to the lack of strategic options available. There really is no bluffing aspect to this game, as you will be penalized greatly for not being 100% committed to a column. The investment cards make for some difficult choices. We have fun in the moments when we realize that the other person has the card that we need. My wife and I would rather suffer play the deeper Battle Line (and risk getting pissed off at each other when we realize that we have no hope in winning a column!).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game to play with someone who has a bit of time, but not the drive to learn a bunch of rules.  My wife and I enjoy it, and we actually have a wonky way of scoring.  (This avoids unnecessary housework due to bad tempers after the game.)  Instead of adding all points and then multipliers, we multiply everything positive first, then take off points.  i.e. If we only had 10 points on an expedition, the rules would have us at minus 10 (-20 for the trip) and then  any multipliers are done.  So if we had two &quot;helper&quot; cards, (sorry, I forget the name), we would be at minus 30!  In our system, the same 10 points are multiplied first by 3, then subtract the 20 for the trip, giving us 10 points to the good.  (For a kinder, gentler world.) For all you single guys out there scoffing at my rule change, just wait till you&#039;re married!  
FYI = Have you heard of the RISK rule that states that ties are won by the female, regardless of who attacked?(Sorry, I have to go, my wife is calling me.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The theme gets completely lost during play. Fortunately, the cards are nice to look at. I'll play it if someone asks, will hardly suggest it myself, though.

RATING: 6.5
A nice little spit of a game. Having this explorer theme connected to a very basic number system made me pause....... oh, the beauty in simplicity.  A lost city theme isn't even constructed with the physicality of this game, rather it just suggests some imagery to be created in your mind...it just lets you fool yourself into feeling a little atmospheric pleasure.  

I mean you could tear up a slab of toilet paper, put some numbers on each piece and play this game.  but i don't recommend it.  

update:  Meh.  this game is so frustrating because you have to wait......that is the strategy- who manages their bad luck the best as they wait for their cards to come in.

RATING: 7
Very easy to understand but complex enough to make it fun to play!  Has been approved by the whole family, including seniors.  You rely a little on luck and a little on strategy and it can get surprisingly competitive if you try to hoard the cards you know your opponent needs.  Not my favorite game (the only reason it's an 8 and not a 9-10), but it's a nice quick one to change up the pace between longer and more complex games.

It can play very well with 4 players at once if you buy a second game box - which was well worth it for our family.  You can play 2 games at once and then swap partners until you've played all 3 (over the course of 3 games).  Alternately, you can use one board and 2 decks of cards and let all 4 players use the same discard pile while building their own stacks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game.  It's extremely simple to learn and I often turn to this game to play with new gamers.  I also feel like it pretty accurately simulates risk-taking with respect to undertaking a new venture.  One might really plan well before they undertake a new expedition.  I enjoy the late portion of Lost Cities when players think things are under control and suddenly realize the game is about to end because the deck is running out and rush to finish their expeditions.

I have seen players using some techniques to slow the end of the game by pulling worthless cards from the discard piles rather than pulling new cards.  It becomes fun towards the end of the game to leverage this technique to try and speed up the end of the game to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Simple, uberlight, contentless game, lots of luck involved and rarely fun. Extremely pasted-on theme. It's basically cards you try to put into number-order and it really is nothing more than that. I think Knizia is running an experiment of how little design you can put into a game and still call it a boardgame, charge 20€ for it and get away with it. Only reason to play it is because it requires minimal effort and is very easy to whip out with the wife at any stage of exhaustion and that is why it will keep seeing a lot of plays and stay in my collection.

RATING: 8.5
The mechanics of this game are straightforward, but the psychological component is delectable. ("Hmmm...my wife hasn't gone on any expeditions yet. Is she waiting for wager cards? Is she just waiting for me to go on another expedition so that she can get rid of several cards that she knows I want? Am I possibly overthinking this, or am I not thinking about it enough?") Each game goes by rather quickly, and I always enjoy the risk-reward balancing for each expedition. Of course, it's never ideal when an expedition results in a negative score, but that's just part of the fun!

RATING: 6
Gyors, két személyes játék, ahol öt színben 2 és 10 közötti értékű kártyákat játszunk ki. Minden lapból csak egy van a pakliban, és csak emelkedő számsorrendben lehet kijátszani őket, így meg kell fontolni a döntéseket. Ha nem akarunk lerakni lapot, el is dobhatunk egyet annak színe szerint, de ezek később felhúzhatóak a játékosok által, szóval amit nem akarunk az ellenfélnél lerakva látni, azt inkább ne dobáljuk. Mindezek mellett a számok előtt "fogadás" kártyákat is kijátszhatunk, amik 2x, 3x, vagy akár 4x pontértéket adnak egy-egy színünknek. 
Amikor a húzópakli kimerül, összeszámoljuk a pontjainkat, de minden szín, amiben lapot raktunk le -20-ról indul! Megdöbbentő módon a legtöbb pont nyer!

Klasz játék, olcsó, sokszor újrajátszható, több féle nyerő stratégia is elképzelhető - csak ajánlani tudom azoknak, akik ketten (is) szoktak játszani.
