RATING: 3
I played many rounds and realized there is no "strategy" part in this game. It's pure luck. When you are forced to play tacticaly due to lack of good cards from the start, you are ussually punished even more by randomly drawing other wrong cards. Also I observed that player who draws more high valued cards, wins it. No matter how smoothly your lower value cards are played. This is the second most stupid game I have ever played, first place goes to something about mob money value bluffing which can be decided by a 50/50 draw. P.S. the obvious playability with classic deck of cards was first thing that I thought of after open it, so much for originality...

RATING: 7
This is a wonderful balance between strategy and luck, with the tensions coming from holding onto a card, playing it, or discarding it.  A lot of times, you don't want to discard something too soon, and a lot of times, you won't want to discard ANYthing from your hand.  It has a lot of agony for such a small box.  The game may get old after many repeat playings, but it still provides a challenge greater than other games your family is willing to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Lost Cities is a card game from the Kosmos two-player series. The object is to mount profitable expeditions to one or more of the five different lost cities. Card play is quite straightforward, with a few agonizing moments sprinkled through what is mostly a fast-moving game. If you start a given expedition, you'd better make some progress in it, or it'll score you negative points. If you can make a lot of progress, you'll score quite well. After three rounds, the highest total score takes the day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Nothing crazy here, just 60 cards with numbers and colors. Yet, it's great.  Quick and easy to teach.  Some people I've played with get frustrated when they don't do well, but after a few plays they tend to get it.  I like that it's simple, but has lots of tension and you need to really think about what to do on your turn.  Luck certainly plays a part, but I believe skill wins this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Amazingly high strategic depth to rules complexity ratio.  Seriously, reading the rules, and maybe even through the first game, it seems there's nothing there.  But it's there.

The tension is all wrapped up in timing.  Essentially, the longer you wait, the better chance of getting a huge payout.  But you have to do *something* each turn, which leads to excruciating decisions.  You also have to make sure you don't wait too long or the deck will run out with good cards still in your hand.

Our first time playing this we intended to just play one learning game and it turned into a four hour session.  That's the sign of a good game.  We don't play as much as we used to because I always win and Allison gets sick of that. :p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very fun relaxing two player game that can cause tension, but not super stressful.  At first, can be a little mathy when adding up the scores, but once you get the hang of it can be really fun.  Definitely a lighter game that you need to play multiple times in order to build a strategy for the game.  love playing this game with my girlfriend who tends to kill me everytime.

RATING: 7
The game I introduced to my girlfriend to get her into boardgaming. I know, very cliche, but it worked! Fun little game that allows just enough decision making to seem like a skilled player will win most of the time.

UPDATE: Apparently, I've been playing the game wrong with whole time! 50+ plays! My girlfriend and I have been calculating the handshake multipliers BEFORE we deduct the 20 points for starting an expedition...
After telling my girlfriend, we decided that we'll keep playing it how we've been playing it. Especially, seeing as she has won twice as many games as I have...

Well, that's what happens when I teach EVERY game we play. I'm going to miss one here or there...

RATING: 7
We have taken our 1999 edition with us camping over the years and this game has opened the eyes of many kids to the world of table top games.  The kids really get into the world expedition theme and it helps them understand the -20 investment cost. It is such a joy to watch the kids just learning arithmetic adding the cards in their heads and on their fingers as well as agonizing over breaking their run or fearing that they have given away a valuable card. This is my standard of a great gateway game.  It can be explained in five minutes yet has enough depth in decision making to have an appeal for all of us.

RATING: N/A
Card game, the object is to mount profitable expeditions to one or more of the five different lost cities. If you start a given expedition, you'd better make some progress in it, or it'll score you negative points. If you can make a lot of progress, you'll score quite well. After three rounds, the highest total score takes the day.

Awards
1999 Meeples' Choice Award
2000 International Gamers Award.

RATING: 8
Just bought this two weeks ago and have already played it close to 100 times... sweet! Very easy to learn and, so, very easy to teach to others. Also love how fast-paced the games are. Downside: I think we've played ourselves out of this one, to be honest. It's starting to get repetitive and I've noticed that a good starting hand (investments at the beginning in a suit that you have a few good cards in) pretty much guarantees victory, so our games swing back and forth a lot.

Edit: Okay, this is still so much fun to play. We've been playing it zany: go big or go home with the investments, and it's taken on a whole new level of awesome. Upgrade that rating!

RATING: N/A
Christmas 2017
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
This game has a grip on me unlike any other game.  It also has one of the worst pasted-on themes any gamer will ever run across.  

"... embark upon adventurous expeditions..."

I'm someone who will stretch to marry theme with mechanics in games because I enjoy picturing myself accomplishing quests or duties as a character in whatever game I'm playing.  I normally am able to find real connections, so my brain becomes more tickled with realism and enjoyment.

Lost Cities is too big a challenge for me to imagine anything but laying down cards and scoring points.  The only thing other then the numbers on each card I look at are its color.  

I LOVE THIS GAME THOUGH!

As each player continues to draw, discard or lay down cards, tension increases dramatically.  Games are ALWAYS tight.  When there are only 10 or so cards left, I'm constantly counting my cards, viewing my card stacks and calculating what my opponent needs to garner positive points.

Games end in a flourish.  Each player, after holding back from committing too much to their own card stacks during the entire match, are now laying down cards as if they're on fire.

Games are short, tense, and nerve afflicting affairs. Lost Cities is very re-playable.  Though not the deepest game tactically or strategically, it is tactically and strategically amazingly deep for its simplicity.

One of Knizia's very best.  Buy it.  :)       
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There is a surprising amount of tension between this choice or that.  Herr Knizia has done it again for sure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not a very heavy game but a little more than meets the eye. My wife loves this game. She beats me at it regularly. It has rules that are short and simple so it is easy to start a pick up game with somebody. 

I enjoy this game because it is straight forward, plays fast and is short, but with tension and some hard decisions. It can be argued that this game can be broken down to a very simple cost optimization strategy. It seems that there is an optimal and calculable move each turn similar to Blackjack. This does not really take into account that your opponent is balancing whether to discard a card which may help you or play a sub-optimal card for themselves. This is a game with only one mechanism but one that is well chosen and balanced for this type of game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My god I love this game!! I haven't kept track of every play before 2016, but it's no exaggeration to say that I've played it about 100 times. We always play best of three and often would do that 2-3 per week nearly every week for a couple of years.

It's quick, but frustrating in having to play a card before drawing a new card, forcing you to play when you don't necessarily want to. It's a wonderful game that can burn you or reward you for waiting too long or just long enough before playing. 

Yes the theme is just plastered on, but it's a card game and I'm rarely playing cards for the theme.

Highly recommended! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Sorry, but it's just two player solitaire.  And could be played just as well with a straight deck of cards using suites instead of these cards.  The art is nice enough, and the quality of the components stands up...but the gameplay is non-existent.  I may well be biased as I've found few 'German games' that I like - too much abstraction, and the themes almost always feel 'tacked on'.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is simply a great 2-player card game. The theme is thin (but then it is a Knizia game), but the gameplay is so strong that it doesn't seem to matter. It's a simple set collection game, except both players may well be competing for the same sets. On top of that players can cause their opponent major difficulties by holding cards that they know their opponent needs. The rules are simple: literally play a card and then pick up a card until there are none left, and then count up the points that each player has. Any set with eight or more cards in it gains a player an extra 20 points. Play and enjoy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
good two player game.  simple rules, but they lead to difficult decisions.  easy to teach.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 6
One of the more overrated games out there.  This one was a blast initially, but after 2 or 3 games the general strategy is fairly well known and so it comes down to who gets the best draw.  The decisions 'feel' tough, but I'm not sure it's really an agonizing decision or just being in a spot where all your options look bad.  Balloon Cup is a much better 2-player Kosmos game.

RATING: 7
It is a simple rummy-style game with a Knizia twist: you have multiple things you want to do, but can't do them all.  You want to play multiple cards. But you can't.  You want don't want to discard or play. But you must.  You want to pick up multiple cards. But you can't.  Simple decisions.  Multiple strategies.

RATING: 7.5
8.5 after our first session.  I love the fact that it is so quick and easy to pick up.  For now, I belong to the group of guys whose wives pound them at this game.  I really enjoy the almost constant tense decisions.

Edit:  After our second play, I drop it to an 8 since I managed a 97 on the first hand.  A little more luck and less skill than I had originally thought.

Edit:  We have played this a lot, but I don't love it like I was hoping.  Maybe that has to do with the fact that my wife doesn't really love it (ie it isn't one of her favorites).  Anyway, it is an okay filler, but I can see myself liking BattleLine more (I've only played that once).

-->Given to Kevin McGrath

RATING: 6
I really like the hand management game play involved, but the mathy scoring bit turns a lot of people off, and also a lot of people don't seem to see the strategy and interaction involved. This game definitely has interaction, but it requires a good bit of observation and memory and is subtle enough that many people seem to miss it entirely and think it's a pretty solitary experience.
